My small group was lucky enough to find parking near the bottom of the steps, and there weren't too many people, so we took lots of photos of both the steps and the view of the city. Definitely worth a quick visit!
author: Sarah B.

description: If your in the city and have seen all the typical places stop by here and be in for a treat. The 16 tiled steps (that are way more than 16 lol) is a pretty hike to a beautiful and different view of SF. During the week there is few people and is quiet and peaceful. There is some street parking where the steps start or at the top on Moraga if you get in and out quick. Great cardio and breath taking view on a sunny clear day. Take it off the SF bucket list.
author: Theresa G.

description: I love this place my wife and I came here earlier In the morning there were only a few people here. We took tons of pictures get here early folks
author: Sam W.

description:
Beautiful mosaic tiled steps in the Golden Gate Heights neighborhood... Located near the base of Grand View Park where 16th Ave hits Moraga St. The tiles are beautifully arranged to create mosaics. Great to look up at from the base. And im sure great exercise too with a great view as a reward once you reach the top.

It's a nice stop in the City that's not your tyipcal tourist destination although you will find those here too. The sides of the long staircase also has nicely manicured plants and flowers. 

Very nice neighborhood find. One of the many reasons I am proud of my hometown.
author: Chuck D.

description:
At 16th and Moraga lies the tiled steps, which is a beautiful collection of art tiles that line up and beautify the city of San Francisco. It goes up the hill to 15th. There were a group of people exercising by running up and down the steps. Oh dear gosh ._. That is intense. Parking is really easy. Either park down on 16th so you can walk up and then down, or park on 15th so you can enjoy the view :)

Grand View Park's entrance is really close by, so you can go up there as well. Why? They have an amazing 360 view of San Francisco. :)
author: Raymond L.

description:
I finally decided to work out, and what's better to start off with stairs :)
Easy way to find this place. Plenty of parking ,but kind of scary that they have signs to take all your valuables with you. 
I only made it twice up and down the stairs 335steps x2= 670steps . My legs felt like Jello afterwards hahahaha 
I will come back again,but this time early in the morning . Found out this was a tourist attraction .It started to get a bit crowded so it might be hard to workout.Loved the view on Top, and beautiful well kept tiles on the steps . Also nice succulant garden too !
author: Daisy R.

description: They're a free attraction and they're absolutely stunning. 10/10 recommend going! It can be hard to get a picture since there's so many people there so I recommend mornings or weekdays!
author: Ashley J.

description:
Wow! I came here at dusk to meet a friend who lives in SF. The stairs are beautiful in daylight and at night. Surprisingly, it also wasn't that crowded and I managed to get a few shots without anyone else in them.

Everyone should take a walk in these stairs. In fact, I'd like to sit and read here next time I got back. Very zen
author: Pam Y.

description:
Definitely a must-see while in Mission... The tiled steps create a beautiful mosaic piece when you look from below & there's a few different pieces. The art is so gorgeous!

And please go during the day so you can capture all its beauty. Thanks :)
author: Olivia S.

description:
BEAUTIFUL STAIRCASE! There'll be a lot of people.

These steps are incredibly close to Grandview Park (where you have a nice view of SF):

+START FROM THE TOP of the steps, and make your way to another set of steps that go up the cemented wall you will see in front of you. The steps are a little right of  the 16th avenue steps. 
+From there, another set of wooden steps are located to the right from the top of the cemented steps. These new set of winding steps lead you up towards the small park. It's engrossed in a lot of trees. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge from here.

Such great spots for photos and a mini workout haha.
author: Telena V.

description:
I have a visitor in town so I got to play tourist this weekend. We parked near 16th Ave and checked out the beautiful mosaic steps. It's a wonderful place to take in the local scenery and enjoy the art on the steps. Plus, you're sort of getting a leg workout. 

It took us a long time to walk up the steps since we stopped so many times for photos. It was my first time visiting and it won't be my last. Once you get to the top, you can take some more steps and head up to Grandview Park, which has, well, you guessed it, a grand view of the entire city.
author: Yi Z.

description: I have been frequenting the Bay Area since I was a child. Being stationed there with my father and family than later on residing for work there for 4 months. I also have a abundance of relatives and close friends who reside in SF and its surrounding areas. So why did it take me this long to find out about these amazing artistic steps. Well they were created not to long ago in the Sunset community of the Bay Area and also I finally had a chance to return after leaving California my home than for over a decade. So it was a nice treat to return and play tourist and discover these steps with my little one and her godmom (who is originally from the island) the creation was awesome and to view it in person is a must. we climbed to the top to witness the beautiful view of the city and to be nosiy of where it lead. O enjoyed seeing the gardens being erected in each of the residence yards. My daughter enjoyed the flight of stairs and we all enjoyed the beauty it brought. This mosaic tiles are a must see on 16th avenue.
author: Cecile Kikilia A.

description: Definitely a gorgeous place to take some candid pics on the tiled steps. I went there around noon, and it was also your typical chilly SF day. There were quite a few people walking up and down/stopping to take pics when I got there. I'll probably go a little earlier (and walk to the top if I don't have my knee brace on) next time I get the chance to stop here.
author: Cass V.

description:
What a beaut! 

Residential parking at both the top and bottom of the stairs so parking can be tight. I parked on 14th Avenue at the entrance of Grand View Park where parking was more available then walked down to the steps. 

I love that there are different pieces/themes throughout the staircase. Walk all the way to bottom to see how they all come together! It's a popular tourist attraction so expect a crowd, but there are a good amount of different pieces so don't worry, you'll get a good photo with at least one of them. Definitely worth a visit!
author: Linh V.

description: Feeling stressed? Come right up these steps to a best view of the Sunset, Outer Richmond, and Ocean Beach! It literally takes my breath away each time I'm at the top.
author: Julio B.

description:
Beautiful place to visit in a nice neighborhood of SF. There were succulents and various other plants planted around the staircase, most of them labelled. The tiled mural on the staircase was beautiful, and it's a great photo-op if you are lucky enough to catch a moment when there's no one in the frame. That's one drawback of the place: there's too many people taking pictures so you might have to stop once in a while. But people will generally stop for you so...it's just giving back.

The view just climbing the staircase is beautiful. After you get to the top, you can keep going on another staircase on the side that leads up to Grand View park--a small park on a hill that offers an even better view of San Francisco. Both places are well-maintained and make for a nice short excursion. There are signs posted everywhere about possible break-ins, so take valuables with you!
author: Jessica L.

description:
How does one go up 163 steps to get to the top? We got some guidance from some kids on the block:

Step by step
Ooh baby
Gonna give it a whirl
Step by step
Ooh baby
Really want to see this world

Step 1: We can have lots of fun
Step 2: There's so much we can do
Step 3: It's just what you want to see
Step 4: I can keep running up lots more
Step 5: Don't you know you're so alive

Step by Step
Don't you know there's a lot more too
Step by Step 

Nestled within a residential area on Moraga St. in the Sunset District (about a mile west of Golden Gate Park), The 16th Avenue Tiled Steps Project offers an up close look at mosaic art, a mini workout up stairs, and an obvious spectacular view.

A visit here can be a quick 5 minute stop for some photo ops (or 10 minutes for those that literally take like 30 different selfies for every 1 pic that they end up posting), or a longer stay that includes some time atop Grand View Park. 

We arrived early on a breezy Saturday morning with moist steps and stayed in the area for nearly 2 hours. It was pretty easy to get up the stairs and there is a reward for getting to the top - the view looking down over the city is more impressive than the artwork on the steps themselves.

The dichotomy of the steps being a tourist spot and a local gem was apparent. We saw someone practically fall on their ass while moving backwards when using their selfie stick, but mainly encountered well-mannered locals walking their dogs or taking an early morning stroll.

This isn't a site one can accidentally come across while driving on a major street. I suggest looking up the location and taking Uber or even Muni to get here. You'll instantly know you're at the right place based on the pics. It's not to be confused with the Hidden Garden Steps on 16th & Kirkham, or The 15th Ave Steps Park, or the wooden steps leading to the top of Grand View Park.
author: Brandon C.

description: I'd heard about these for an awfully long time but never knew exactly where they were. They're a perfect destination following a quick stop at Home and Twisted Donuts nearby, and the views of both the stairs & the ocean (on a clear day) are amazing!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Love these steps!!!!! Must see!!!!! This is the correct address! 

16th Ave & Moraga St, San Francisco 94122

The one that is viewed on yelp didn't take me to the correct location.
author: Katelin N.

description:
I swear I'm a sucker for beautiful architecture and artwork. After seeing it on IG for years, I decided it's finally time I make a visit to these famous mosaic steps. Of course, my pictures didn't do justice of how vibrant it really looks as I upload it from my go pro. 

We were able to find street parking nearby and make a quick visit just to take pictures on the stairs. Maybe if we wore proper outfits then we'd probably walk it all the way up to see what the view was like. But we were on a time limit as well so we just made quick photoshoot one for the memory books. 

I loved how each set of tiles were different from each other that make each walking set of steps unique and beautiful. Surprisingly there wasn't really any one there so we enjoyed the view to our self for a bit as we only went 1/3 of the way just to get our pictures. ;) I wouldn't mind actually hiking up these stairs the next time I ever come around this area.
author: Roxanne Lynn T.

description: what a beautiful landmark! i love how the mosaic design tells a story, resembling the sea, then the earth, then the sky. you can use this place as an outdoor stair masters too! bring your camera because you'll definitely have some great views of SF!
author: Jamie C.

description:
Ladies leave your men at home for this one but this not only is a good photo spot but an amazing view .... 

Appreciating this art is must do on the list of coming to San Francisco.
author: Lesley M. C.

description:
I don't know if it's just us, but all our adventures we did at SF consist of stairs.
We were basically active the whole week we were there. I loved it!
Must-visit place if you're around SF--the reward on top is incredible: Grand View Park!
When we visited, it wasn't really crowded, and it was amazing checking out all these mosaic tiles.
It's a great additional to the neighborhood, and there are about 163 steps.
Once you're on top, look back and you get to see these incredible views of the city.
Parking can be difficult but we were lucky to find a space for our car.
Only to find out that this Asian snobby lady was kicking us out "because she was calling the tow truck already". Luckily, we were heading out anyways. 
Overall, must check this place out when you're around, just good luck with parking :D
author: Laramae E.

description: I went early enough on a Sunday morning, so it wasn't that crowded.  It was overcast, but still a wonderful view up at the top.  Each set of stairs have a different theme.  It was an easy walk and the tiles are beautiful.  When you reach the top.  You can also walk up to Turtle Hill for a 180 view at the top where you can see downtown in the distance.
author: Cat C.

description:
Your review helps others learn about great local businesses.

Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.
author: Habibti A.

description:
The views from here are amazing and breathtaking. Although the day we went was a bit chillier than expected even at the end of June in mid summer. I loved it and the many steps. 

Tip#1 my cousin told me "Don't look back until you make it to the very top!"
author: Minjee Y.

description: Beautiful artwork done on the steps! This is one of the cooler and must visit places when in San Francisco. It is very neat to see the designs that the tiles have that are placed on all the steps. I've come by to walk up the steps and admire the artwork several times. There are always a lot of people walking the steps in both directions, up and down the steps. It's pretty cool to take pics with the art on the steps. Just watch out for accidental photobombing because there'll definitely be tons of people trying to take pics all at the same time.
author: Brandon D.

description:
Remember, there's more than just one!

If you're like me and can't "relax" on a vacation, this is one little adventure that will certainly keep you on your feet and work those leg muscles. San Francisco's secret mosaic staircase is an exciting mini adventure that will kill about an hour or two of your day depending on how quick you move and how many of the steps you're looking to see. Not only are you going to see some amazing views of the city, you'll also get to take in the beauty of tile art as the flowing mosaic runs up 163 steps and swirls around for even more steps that lead up to Grand View Park. 

Now, there's a few steps to take in all the steps that are accounted for with this escapade as most people only come for the middle steps on 16th Avenue (between Noriega St. & Moraga St.). But there is also another flight of stairs from the 15th Avenue Steps Park (corner of Kirkham St. and 15th Ave.). It's only a 5 minute walk between the two and the 15th Avenue Steps Park is certainly less crowded though overlooked I would guess since it's all under the shade of the trees and doesn't shine quite as bright.  These of course steer you to Grand View Park which offers massive views of the city and Golden Gate Park. All are definitely a hidden gem worth seeking out and conquering, plus it's another completely free escape from the city. Be sure to shout down upon the San Franciscans below.
author: Chris M.

description: Great picture opportunity.  Stairs are beautiful - truly a work of art. View from top also very scenic.  Definitely a good stop for those visiting as they are driving through the Sunset district of the city.  We spent about 15-20 there...a quick stop.
author: rowena n.

description:
One of the greatest views in San Francisco!

After trying to find this place for a while now, my friends and I finally got to come here. Parking wasn't a problem for us when we went. We conveniently found one literally across the street.

It was also perfect when we went because there wasn't a lot of people so we were able to take some great pictures. The steps were a workout but that's totally fine! On top of the stairs, you could see Moraga clearly and the beach.

It was definitely a breathtaking experience with an awesome view and I highly suggest coming here.
author: Aj C.

description: If you're from Orange County, this spot reminded me of 1000 steps in Laguna Beach except with beautifully decorated tiles. Once you find the steps on 16th street you're going to have to walk up the flight of stairs to get the amazing view at the top. It's worth the stop when you're in San Francisco and it's a nice little exercise too.
author: Joann D.

description: The famous 16th avenue stairs have become a landmark in San Francisco.  Because it lives near Sunset, it is relatively secluded from tourists.  Its a great place to catch a sunset with a loved one or friends.  Offers a great view on a clear day and gives a very different perspective of the more residential side of SF.  Can be nice to catch your breath here away from the hustle and bustle of city center.  Very often, you'll see residents running the stairs.  At sunset, the mosaic pieces on each flight of stair do a great job reflecting and casting light back to the viewer which results in an intimate and gorgeous view both direction.
author: David C.

description:
I lived in the Sunset all through my childhood and early 20's.  This place is such a beautiful addition to the area.  I love the tiny details on the tiles and the breathtaking view from the top.  Definitely a must see.  Take lots of pics and bring your favorite person or people.  I brought my mom who is one of my favorite people and we just took it all in.   

If you have the energy, walk all the steps up and enjoy the breathtaking view of our beautiful city.  Parking is ample and it's never been too crowded when I visit.   Definitely love at first sight, just like the city of San Francisco.  The city of my dreams...
author: Christine P.

description:
This is definitely worth the hike. The beautifully mosaic tiled steps and the breathtaking view of SF, why would you miss this? 

Also thank you, old asian lady for making it so memorable. We woke up early to avoid any busy tourist crowds to take pictures here. A few people were here, and we tried waiting for the asian lady to stop exercising in the middle of the steps. We couldn't politely wait any longer because her routine went on for a good 12 minutes. Thank you, asian lady, for photobombing our pics with high kicks.

Please check this place out. Words can't do it justice.
author: Glo K.

description:
It was my first time in sf and I wanted to come here for pictures. I didn't notice the yelp pictures until after the incident. As I was walking towards the steps I saw multiple signs "DAY TIME CAR THEFT." I didn't think much of it because I didn't have anything in my rental.

As I was walking back to the rental, I saw one guy peeking through the window and my alarm going off. I took a video of them as they drove off. Nothing was taken so I got into my car. As I was driving away, they circled back and started cursing and threatening us about taking their picture. Why are they so defensive then if nothing happened? They were obviously trying to get into a tourist rental since the license plate was from a different state. 

Very dangerous area. Since they are aware of this situation, they should put up surveillance cameras to prevent these thefts.
author: Jason L.

description:
The "Moraga Steps" or the "Mosaic Steps" or the "Tiled Steps" or the "Grand View Park Steps"....whatever! Call them what you will... these steps are both beautiful themselves and provide beautiful views of the city. The adventure can be extended by making it all the way to the top of the hill to Grand View Park.

I discovered these steps by looking for "Local Flavor" spots in SF on Yelp-. I took my kids here recently and it was very cool. Even with the extended adventure to the "top of the hill" at Grand View Park it wasn't a very long visit, maybe 30 minutes round trip if you start at the base of the stairwell. Its a photogenic spot for a number of reasons, so come prepared to take pictures. The city views, the stairwell, and the close-ups of the tile art are all cool for pictures.

The [arking situation isn't too bad. It's all residential so be conscious of the signs.

The stairs are hugged on both sides by well manicured gardens.

I will definitely be returning.
author: David S.

description: Hidden gem tucked away in this residential area! The mosaic steps were created by the community and continue to be maintained by them. It is truly a lovely piece of work. Parking is decent in the area since this is more of a photo op. Definitely climb to the top once to see the breathtaking view of Ocean Beach in the distance. Come during sunset for great pictures and a great view from the top. You'll probably spend no more than 15 minutes here, but worth putting on your list of places to visit in the city.
author: Kristi T.

description:
Finally went! Well, perhaps a certain 2D project propelled me to do so but that's besides the point. :)

This project was started in 2003, and this was my first time visiting. 

Mosaic tiles = awesome! Make sure to take a closer look at each step...so much detail!  I'll have to back at a later time, when it's not a blinding sun in the eyes. And the plants surrounding the steps were amazing, too.  It was breathtaking! 

So we climbed and climbed, and enjoyed the view to the ocean, and the Golden Gate Bridge. But if you walk up, take a right and walk up another lengthy set of wooden steps to Grand View Park, you'll appreciate the 360 views of San Francisco.  Holy cow.  Just enjoy the view and hope it's not too windy to blow you off.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I first learned about these steps through Pinterest, then came over to yelp to see if it was worth my while.  To find them when you are in the city, just use google maps and they will take you to the bottom of the steps.  It is in a residential area, but it's relatively easy to find - just follow the steady trickle of people around that area and you'll either see the steps or the sign.  It's hard to get a picture without anyone on the steps, due to the popularity of them with the locals and tourists.

The mosaic tiles on the steps are amazing, and the colors seem to pop more when they are in the shadows.  Although you could make out all the designs without going all the way up the stairs, I suggest that you still do - each flight between the landings are a different theme and it's easier to get pictures of each landing without anyone in there than the whole flight of steps.  I think the steps look more intimidating then they actually are.  Plus, the views at the top are amazing!
author: Megan L.

description: Very nice and beautiful... too many people though... you can go all the way up and go to another highest top after... where you can see kinda the city from the top... pretty cool
author: L D.

description:
My pops...he's funny...

He's proudly called San Francisco his home for over 25 years now--considers The City, in fact, as an old friend of his--however, the 163 mosaic-tiled steps off 16th and Moraga had somehow (to his amazement) remained elusive.  As with everything treasured, The 16th Avenue Tiled Steps Project--hidden within the secret nooks and crannies of Golden Gates Heights--was just waiting patiently to be curiously stubbled upon someday, to be eagerly sought out and unveiled by any and all adventurers with eclectic whims for the aesthetic. 

Enter one, very cool son (thank you very much) to allow for introductions... 

Beautifully patterned and intricately colored, the Project began back in January of 2003, and was ceremoniously inaugurated on August 27th, 2005.  Artists Aileen Barr and Colette Crutcher--inspired by the famed Escadaria Selarón Steps in Rio de Janeiro--initiated the creation.  Hundreds of enthusiastic volunteers from the neighboring communities stepped up and offered their time and support; and as a result, their vision, their hard work and devotion, their revelation is nothing short of stunning!
author: Craig F.

description: There's nothing more humbling than having to stop every 10 steps & pretending you're "admiring the view" because you don't want to admit (to yourself more than to your partner) that you're an out-of-shape sloth who really shouldn't have stopped going to your weekly Zumba class.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I went on a small adventure in the city and this was on my list of things I wanted to go to that day. We took muni and a bus to get there. 

We went on a gorgeous day and hiked up all the steps. The view at the top is gorgeous. You can see all the houses and the beach. Also Golden Gate Bridge. 

Walking up the steps you notice the great detail put into creating it. I liked how it starts with the ocean and sea life and as you climb up you see flowers, then the moon and at the top there's the sun. I definitely want to come back here.
author: Kalani M.

description: tricky to get to the first time but worth it! it is such a cute little stop while in SF!
author: Sara S.

description:
I came here with my sister on a sunny day, but it was quite windy, especially as we climbed all the steps to reach the top of the land.

The scenery:
It was such a beautiful 360-view of the city. The tiled steps were beautiful, as I had to stop every few section of steps to turn around and take pictures of the tiles. I bet that it's very beautiful here when there are clear skies at night with the city lights turned on. I would like to see the sun setting when we come back at the right time, but you really do get to see a lot up here.

Exercise level:
I am guilty of not exercising as much as I should. You can probably say that I am pretty much a couch potato. However, these steps can give a pretty good leg workout. My quads became sore really quick lol. I saw another visitor jogging up and down the tiled steps with his dog following behind him. These steps are great for leg days. As you reach the top where there are more stairs after crossing a road, it gets to be very windy. I was pretty much out of breath but I took my time. 

Parking:
Parking here is not too hard to find, but just watch out for street cleaning signs. It's pretty hilly getting up here to park close by and also the narrow and windy roads, but the neighborhood seems to be generally very quiet and peaceful.

Safety:
What threw me off a bit about this park was seeing a lot of warning signs about car thefts. I'm guessing the neighbors across the streets know a lot about that. They're probably watching out for the visitors who come here daily. It's unfortunate that people can't enjoy their views and exercise without having to worry about their cars getting broken into, or even the park's plants getting stolen. Because of these signs, I try to be more aware and not stay too long whenever I come to this park, but so far, my experiences here have been safe and enjoyable ones.
author: Em S.

description: Taking in the local flavor of the city. We drove specifically to visit these steps and they didn't disappoint. Found parking easily on the street below. Beautiful tiled stairs made of mosaics (I thought they were painted when I was told about them). We got there an hour or so before sunset so it was getting dark but there was still a good amount of people there. Some took the opportunity to do a photo shoot (???) which makes it difficult for others to walk up the stairs and take their own pictures. But it was still a nice local spot and got a mini workout. We walked to the top (about 140~ steps) and enjoyed the view of the city. Quick tourist stop and a unique part of the city.
author: Haneen O.

description:
These stairs are nothing short of amazing. 163 steps of art put together by over 300 neighbors within the Golden Gate Heights area all leading up to the summit of Grand View Park (which actually has multiple entrances, but none prettier than this obviously). I love showing friends and relatives of this "secret" spot in San Francisco. 

And now there's even more reason to visit because another mosaic staircase is located a just bit away on Kirkham as well!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Love! One of the best views in SF.
author: Jen J.

description: Beautiful tiles steps. Make sure to go on and nice sunny day. Can get pretty windy and cold at times..
author: Kay S.

description:
I'm a visual person and love colorful things like this so when I saw this picture on Pinterest/tumblr -- dare I say, it became the push and driving motivation for me to visit San Francisco?! Unfortunately, I never got the chance to see it when I visited last, so I made it my mission to see it this time. It's such a well kept secret though because when I mentioned this to my local friends, none of them had heard of it!

The mosaic is magnificent and a wonderful piece of artwork for the city! Different sceneries are depicted of the earth, the ocean, and as you ascend the staircase, you're traveling out to the moon and then to the sun-- maybe I'm reading too much into it, but I loved how it wove all of nature's elements together!

The stairs aren't difficult to climb and your reward at the top is a breathtaking view of the city! So excited to cross this off my SF bucket list and would not mind coming back to look at it again. I wish there were more of these everywhere!!
author: Angie D.

description: Totally worth the stop. We had a rental car so we didn't have trouble getting to the location. We walked up the stairs then to the park and up to the top of that hill to see the whole city. This is one of the most beautiful views and it was easy for the 2 of us. It's a great place to snap pics. The stairs are beautiful themselves- I love the detail and craftsmanship that went into them. This is a must visit!
author: Lauren N.

description:
After a litte cardio by beautifully decorated steps, you are rewarded with a pretty cool view of the city. I think this is one of those not so hidden spots that will soon become saturated by tourists, worth a visit. 
I enjoy a bit of exercise, not too many steps and this is a spot not to be missed!
Bring a camera and tennis shoes.
author: Frank D.

description: If you don't exercise often, you'll definitely get a workout climbing up these steps.  Fortunately, the beautiful and creative images are a nice distraction.  After reaching the top of the stairs, there are additional stairs to your right and more stairs that take you up to Grand View Park. You'll want to climb up these stairs as you'll get a 360 view of SF!  It's AMAZING!
author: Candice H.

description: AMAZING mosaic steps in SF. They are very close to Hidden Garden steps, so you can do both. They are incredibly! Totally worth checking out.
author: Jen G.

description:
Also known as The Moraga Steps!

This is definitely a must go place in San Francisco. The details on these mosaic steps are just so gorgeously detailed. Every flight of steps displays a different piece of artwork. One of my favorite parts is the moon and the stars. Not only are the steps gorgeous, but the view from the top of the steps is breathtaking as well.

I think the best time to come would be right before the sun sets on a summer evening. That way you don't have too much fog or too much sun.

There's plenty of street parking around when I went (daytime on a random day of the week), which is awesome, because when is parking ever not a hassle in the city?

This is a great place for some photo ops , but keep in mind that some locals come here to get in a good stair-master workout, so be careful not to get in their way!
author: Lincy H.

description: The Tiled Steps at 16th Avenue and Moraga are far more spectacular to see in person.  Though the steps can get crowded, people seem to clear out quickly when the sun starts to set... which makes for great photo opps.  As an added bonus, when you reach the apex of the tiled steps, it's worth crossing the road and climbing another flight of steps for a spectacular pano view of the city.
author: Lee K.

description:
It's cute. It's easy to park, walk up to the top, take a couple of cute pictures, and see a beautiful view.

I don't know that I'd rank this as a top tourist spot, but it really is a nice off-the-beaten path place that not every tourist has done to death, so maybe a nice pit stop when you're driving the in-laws around.
author: Sean B.

description: This place was very busy during my visit which I wasn't surprise. It has great view of the city from the top. And when you walk down is a great view to look up at. The stairs are beautifully made.  Is hard to get a good picture with all of the people around. stop by to see this beautiful art.
author: Asenath N.

description: Located in a residential area, there is street parking and it gets very crowded. The crowds make it hard to get a picture of the staircase without anyone else in the photo, but still a beautiful place to see at least once!
author: Maleah M.

description: Great for a visit any time of day, but rarely without people taking photos and enjoying the sunset view.
author: Steve F.

description:
Gorgeous city view at the top!

Stopped by here with a few friends this past Saturday afternoon to check out the hype. Lots of nearby street parking in this residential area. Moderate crowd of people taking pictures and going up/down the steps. It wasn't too crowded being that it was in the middle of the day on a weekend. 

The flowers and plants were in full bloom and it was beautiful! Each step is a beautiful mosaic of tiles...colorful, artistic, exquisite. I personally do not work out on a regular basis so I did get out of breath when getting to the top of the 163 steps LOL. After admiring each mosaic step, the top of the stairs gives you a rewarding view of the city and the bay. 

**If you want an extra challenge after getting to the top of the mosaic steps, walk across the street to the other stairway and that will bring you up to Grandview Park (more amazing 360 degree views of this beautiful city) :)
author: Jasmine P.

description:
How can you NOT give this place 5 stars?!

It's literally one of San Francisco's hidden gems. Tucked away in the Inner Sunset, coming up here is kinda difficult since you're driving up a hill, but if you're not then its not that bad a walk from 19th ave or other places.

Major major mmaaaajjjoorr props to the artists who made the stairs the way they are. The fact that each step is carefully painted in a mosaic fashion says that these people were definitely dedicated to turning what was once broken into something amazing. They're absolutely beautiful, and viewing them from the bottom to see an astonishing and well-crafted image is worth coming here. 

Walking up the stairs is not only a good workout, but it also rewards your efforts with the view of San Francisco.

Breathtaking.

Its better to come on sunny days when the sun's out and the colors shine, but be warned that the shadows of trees will block some of the steps lol. Foggy days are okay too, but you don't get that rich color in the fog booo!
author: Jerianne G.

description: Beautiful tiled steps taking you up to Grandview Park. Each step has a different color and design. This is free to the public so if you're in town and wanted to see something nice and do something touristy for cheap, this is your spot! I know a friend who even planned his proposal here! She said yes BTW! :P
author: Vivian N.

description:
Wanted something interesting to see so we found this place on Yelp while we were hanging out in San Francisco.

BEAUTIFUL!

There's really isn't much to say because it was breathtaking. Literally, walking up these steps was a struggle! Hahah just kidding, kind of. I loved the mosaic tiles and the picture it formed from straightforward viewpoint. It was colorful and vibrant in every aspect, not to mention very detailed as well. I've never seen anything like this so it was kind of a "hole in the wall" type of landmark. 

The 16th Avenue Tiled Steps project has been a neighborhood effort to create a beautiful mosaic running up the risers of the 163 steps located at 16th and Moraga in San Francisco and I believe they've succeeded impressively. I love the value behind the tiles and how the community came together to fixate it into something more than just steps to run over. It could possibly symbolize much more than just artsy stairs to run up and down on.

What's more beautiful than to experience art that was made by hundred of neighbors for more generations to find? It's really heart-lifting to view such an amazing staircase of steps and its view at the top as well! I recommend if you have the time and are in San Francisco!
author: Sharz T.

description:
My calves really hate me right now!!!

Beautiful mosaic tiled staircase with a breathtaking view of SF once you get to the top.  It's a great place to get a good workout because it's easy to miscount how many times you walk/run up and down the stairs (like I did). Once you get down the the last step, make a right onto 16th St., walk down approx.1/2 mile and you will see Hidden Garden Steps on your left.  I personally like Hidden Garden Step..the stairs are cleaner and more colorful. 

I suggest coming here before sunset or early morning to avoid the crowd.
author: Amy H.

description: This place has a nice view of the west side of San Francisco. I recommend coming early, so you're not around as many tourist.
author: Willem V.

description: These are beautiful steps, easy to get to, walk to the top and enjoy the gorgeous tile designs and the succulent garden as well.  Nice place for photos.
author: Leslie W.

description: My wife and I took a cab to Chow's Restaurant then walk the rest of the way to these steps. Beautiful day and walking area through areas we'd not explored yet. The steps themselves are just beautiful to look at and take lots of photographs of them. Being an artist myself I can really appreciate just how much went into each and every tile here. If you are from out of town visiting I would put this on your SF bucket list of things to do, or see. And even if you live here I would recommend that you check this one off that list. Go see the steps if you haven't yet.
author: Kirk M.

description:
Great place to take visitors in town or to go to when you need to wind down and have some alone time. The mosaic art is beautiful and as you walk up the steps, you'll see a fantastic view of the Pacific Ocean.
It's also great because this was created by a community effort and the unique tiles have individual names and organizations engraved on them. 
There are two different mosaic art staircases- the other one is on 16th and Kirkham. Make sure to check out both! Both are extremely gorgeous- no shame in taking dozens of pictures. :)
author: Grace L.

description:
SO beautiful!  SO creative!  THIS is a hidden San Francisco treasure that you won't find in the guidebooks

Located in Grand View Park, it's easy to miss this objet d'art if you're not seeking it out

Start at the bottom of the stairs & slowly work your way up.....take in all the cute tiles & see how most have a name on them as tribute to the person who made it or to whom it was dedicated

See the different "layers" from sea to sky & marvel in the transformation of our beautiful world

Landscaping of lovely flowers & plants all along the staircase make it *that* much more gorgeous & the scene from the top of the stairs offers yet another breathtaking view of our lovely city
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Came here on a Saturday morning. Mistake there was a ton of people there taking a bunch or pictures and not letting anyone else go up or take any pictures kind of a bummer. Pretty easily accessible have to drive all the way up the big hill for 16th ave. it's propped on a very residential area so parking during a busy time could be difficult. I parked on a residential side street a block over not bad. The art on the steps though are pretty amazing and the view from the top
Is beautiful. I was only there for about 10 minutes, I wouldn't go out of my way to see it but if you are close u I would recommend.
author: Christine V.

description: If you enjoy art than this is an incredible site!! It was a little tough to get there due to GPS mishaps but it was well worth it. There is also an awesome view for clear days above the the stairs. Be ready to wait for many to take pictures or to have many people in your background. If you're a planner and are looking for how long this attraction/tourist stop may take on a Saturday afternoon in early June we took about 30-45 minutes to enjoy the site, snap a few pictures, and then get out and on our way. It's in a neighborhood so please be mindful of the residents when it comes to parking, noise, littering, loitering, and of course stay on sidewalks to not only stay safe but to minimize traffic hold ups and such.
author: Kacie H.

description:
This place is truly a hidden gem because it took my boyfriend and me forever to find it. 

We took the bus to the nearby stop and walked around and around to find it. Finally we found it - hidden away in the neighborhood. We first encountered another set of tiled steps - the Hidden Garden Steps before finding the 16th Avenue one. 

Once we found these steps, we were amazed at how beautiful the mosaic tiles are. It's a truly amazing art project. 

Don't be intimidated by the number of the steps. You'll experience a breathtaking view at the very top. 

We came here on a weekday early evening and not many people were here so it was perfect for photos. After that, we wandered around and found a park nearby because we wanted to see the sunset. We encountered another step of stairs - wooden this time and watched the sunset on top.
author: Yi Xian R.

description: Beautiful tiled steps that seem to stretch on and on...and on. It was quite a trek to get here, but the view was well worth it. We didn't actually climb the steps because our feet were so ruined by this point, but next time! This is a beautiful spot for pictures if you don't mind locals and other tourists being in your shot, as this place is quite popular, even on weekday afternoons. I would stop at the Hidden Garden Steps on your way up to get double the tiled step fun in, and also a quieter experience if that's what you prefer.
author: Katie H.

description:
What a hidden community gem! Found this through Yelp!! I was wondering what else there was besides places to eat in the area of the relatives we were visiting.  

Amazing tiled artwork & creativity!  There's approximately 131 stairs, (my 4yr old counted so add or minus a few). They are small steps and there is a 'landing' if you will here in there. Handrails on both sides. 
Fun experience.  Its a community project with unique tiles with individual names and organizations and such engraved on them. They all connect in an artsy way. The succulent garden on each side is pretty cool too, see the different blooms during cooler months.  
Once you get to the top...do a dance....then walk back down but check out the view! Amazing when sun is setting! Parking isn't bad..just be courteous and not to block a driveway.
author: Fer R.

description: Free, cheap, and I don't think many people know about this place.  Great tiled mosaic steps you can run up and take photos.  I imagine you would get a good view of the city but the day we came it was really cloudy.  It is kind of in the middle of nowhere so you'd have to drive or uber.  Hidden gem for sure!
author: Nyla K.

description: Derp. I am not a local but I knew where we were heading. We were showing a friend the steps since it is a local flavor. Well we scored a parking spot, looked up and saw the steps. It is cute. Maybe if it wasnt that freezing with the chance of rain fast approaching we would have explored more or finished the steps but we sorta just derped there. If I was a tourist I dont think I would want to go here but if I was a local or from the area, I guess I would stop by if I had no plans and I wanted to explore the gems and treasures of the city. There are mores steps really close by but I think we got the gist of it from these. Derp
author: Amy H.

description: Amazing photo op & scenery - we went on our way out closer to 6pm & it was beautiful! Apparently they glow in the dark, however, I am not sure I'd be done the steep steps in the dark. Absolutely beautiful tho!
author: Cassie M.

description:
The day I came here, there were people doing a cleaning.  They were very friendly even with all the tourists taking multiple pictures and selfies.  The thing with taking pictures here is unless the 20 steps above you are empty, you'll most likely have a stranger in there.  Better to go really early in the day.

After you are done with these steps, don't leave.  When you're at the very top, cross the small road, and take the steps (a much smaller set) up to Grand View Park.  You won't regret it!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Thank goodness for social media. I found out about this place from my friend's FB picture postings of their SF trips. I knew that I had to check this place out since the pictures looked amazing.

Luckily, my former colleague lives in Cali and he drove my friends and I here. Thank you Google Maps for leading us here and you just type in "16 tile step project."

Pretty much this was one of the main highlights of my SF trip. I loved the beautiful mosaic tile steps. I wished I took more pictures tho. When you reached to the top of the stairs, you'll see a view of the houses below. Then, there's another staircase nearby leading to Grant View Park where you go up the stairs and you'll see another view of SF.

Simply amazing and I wasn't disappointed. I'll try to revisit here again one day.
author: Linda T.

description:
Colorful artsy mosaic staircase!

I love going here because it is a wonderful place to be. The atmosphere, the people, the alert, the exercise, and the view. My first time here was amazing! This was my second time and it was even more exciting showing my friends around this area.

It reminds me of communication hills in San Jose except there's no art there. I don't know if people exercise here though.

Parking should be easy, you just park in the neighborhood and walk over, but be sure not to park where the bus stops are.

If you walk up the staircase then cross the street to the other staircase, go up to the Grand View Park up above and you will experience a breathtaking view! Don't miss out, one of the hot spots in SF with so much art and culture.
author: Tina N.

description:
Beautiful mosaic tiled on the stairs... it tells a lovely story of the moon, the sun and beloved SF. So many great views in all directions from around the steps.
A must visit when in San Francisco.
It is in the Sunset neighborhood, easy to get to.
Plenty of parking around.
author: Kinjal S.

description: These are very cool looking stairs and you get a nice view of the bay and the city once you reach the top!
author: Young Y.

description: I've lived in the Bay Area my whole life and still find new places to discover in the area that I haven't been to before. When my friend and I were going to have a photography day and she suggested we check out the Moraga Steps, I was super excited! This was my first time visiting them and even though it was Saturday afternoon and pretty crowded, everyone was respectful and patient to let others take pictures and experience the views as 'uninterrupted' as possible. We had a blast and appreciated the different mosaic designs on each flight of stairs.
author: Olivia M.

description: Arrived on a rainy day, which allowed for ample parking but less of a view. Yet, the stairs are beautiful and worth a return visit when the weather is better.
author: PleasantonCA C.

description: Great workout in a beautiful space! Walked them three times. Luckily, I happened upon some locals who told me about the second set up on the hill. I made it up both sets, only to have to cut my stay on the hilltop short given the extremely strong winds. This a highlight of my trip and I have good pictures to remember it.
author: Candace W.

description:
Beautiful tiled steps!
A must-see when visiting San Francisco.
author: Maria P.

description:
Long ago in a faraway land called the FiDi I met a young man - more boy than man actually - who I considered a rube.  He had beefy pink, round cheeks, hailed from a faraway place called Idaho, and longed to return there after his limited but life-changing experience in Baghdad by the Bay.   

He left then, and returned again recently with a grown daughter in tow.  He was threatening to take her on a San Francisco tour of "all the places I once lived" before I intervened.  The 16th Avenue Tiles Steps was, both agreed, far superior to what he'd originally planned.  
 
Tucked away in a lightly traveled residential area, the 163 steps which make up this landmark seem like something only very well-connected people would know of.  As a result, you'll likely be startled to see the number of people actually there, climbing the stairs, posing for photos, and ascending higher, to the equally captivating Grandview Park (reached from the top of the tiled steps and up a lot more steps).  

In 2005 - with thanks to the SF Parks Trust, the 300 neighbors who helped make the tiles, and the 220+ neighbors who sponsored individual tiles - the tiled steps were opened for use.  Their popularity doesn't diminish their loveliness.  If you've not yet checked them out, consider doing so.  I guarantee it's more interesting than a tour of the places you once lived.  

*  This area of the City is not as foggy as most people think.  Both times I've visited the views out to the Pacific Ocean have been breathtaking.

*  The steps scale the side of a large hill.  If you have mobility issues you can view from below but the only way to get to the top is walking.

*  Street parking in the area is free.  Be considerate.

*  There's other tiled step projects in the City.  The nearby "Hidden Garden Steps" (http://www.yelp.com/biz/hidden-garden-steps-san-francisco) are complete.  The Lincoln Park Steps (http://www.lincolnparksteps.org/index.html) are a gorgeous work in progress.  I like this trend.
author: Tracey A.

description: The tiled steps are beautiful to look at when your at the bottom of the stairs and you get a great view at the top of the stairs of the city! I love that the steps were a neighborhood effort to create a beautiful mosaic running up 163 steps. This is a very touristy spot so people will be here taking pictures also. It was difficult to get a picture without anyone else in it.
author: Hayley q.

description:
While the flocks of tourists and teenagers trying to snap artsy iPhone pics can get annoying, there's a reason why everyone's here in the first place. 

This is an extremely impressive and unique community art project that is worth heading over to the inner sunset for. As others have mentioned, it's especially beautiful during the latter hours of a sunny day. It also happens to be a completely open, unobstructed vertical strip with spectacular views of the Ocean. 

Make sure to check out the nearby Hidden Garden Steps and venture up into Grand View Park to complete the trip.
author: Andres B.

description:
I absolutely adore these beautiful stairs. 
Each tile, each step, each glorious move up lead to a magnificent view.
Arrive early to avoid crowds, be respectful of residents and enjoy the view, the art and take photos.
Breath taking views, free, fun, unique. 
Just one more thing to love about San Francisco.
author: Zildheam D.

description:
BEAUTIFUL & artistic staircase that is worth driving to and climbing (it's not that hard of a climb and there are handrails for those who need the extra stability). It is just amazing to see the entire staircase artwork from across the street and up close while climbing each step. But of course you won't be the only one who thinks so and so it can be a challenge to get some great photos without people standing in the middle of your photo shoot (or on the stairs itself). I am not sure when is the best time to come when no one is there (perhaps you will just have to play with the times... maybe really early in the morning and later at night?). 

This is definitely a MUST spot for you to come if you visit San Francisco or if you are a local and haven't had a chance to make your way over here. (and work a 2nd or 3rd visit).
author: Vic C.

description: Another beautiful destination worth the little journey, especially if you're in the area. The steps go very high, high enough to get a beautiful view of the ocean. Not to mention the steps themselves which are covered in art on each step. Beautiful mid day stop or photo shoot location.
author: John S.

description: I thought these were just gonna be some nice steps with some nice views but boy was I wrong. I walked here from Golden Gate Park and it was a long way uphill but it was so worth it. I was lucky it was a beautifully clear day so you can see all the way to the Pacific O
author: Susie C.

description:
Not much more to say that hasn't already been said...

Awesome tile work and fantastic view of the city!
author: Liz N.

description:
Of course everyone gives it 5 stars, beauty up, beauty down, exercise and feel your beautiful body work.

Someone called it Stairway to Heaven, how romantic.  I studied every section.

Once you get to the top, their is another set of stairs that goes to the very top of the hill where you can walk in a circle to see the different sides of the city.

Added bonus, there are a couple of geocaches for treasure seekers.
author: Connie W.

description:
Beautifully Tiled and Colourful Steps & Gorgeous Views of the City from the Top - An Off the Beaten Path Hidden Gem in San Francisco! 

My mother and I visited the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps, also known as the Mosaic Steps, on the morning/afternoon of July 30th, after visiting the Golden Gate Bridge. 

The Mosaic Steps were located at the corner of Moraga and 16th Avenue, just south of Golden Gate Park. 

We took the MUNI bus from the Golden Gate Bridge Welcome Center parking lot to the corner of 19th Avenue and Moraga. From there, it was a short walk to the steps. The walk up Moraga Street was on a very steep incline to the base of the stairs. 

We were the only people at the steps at the time and it was nice to be able to explore the entire place on our own. The steps were located in amongst a quiet residential neighbourhood and the atmosphere was very peaceful and relaxed. 

The stairs are a community project (the history of them is interesting and I would encourage you to read up on it) and they were tiled beautifully in a variety of colours, patterns and designs, from the bottom to the top. The artwork was amazing and very impressive. This made for some fantastic photo opportunities, and I enjoyed admiring the work that had been to beautify these steps. 

They were located on a hillside and were surrounded by lush greenery and vegetation, as well as houses. We began climbing. The stairs were on a very steep incline and hiking up them was a great workout! We finally made it to the top and were rewarded with gorgeous panoramic views of the expansive city surrounding us. It was breathtaking and the views were definitely worth the climb! It was incredible how far we could see, from the densely treed Golden Gate Park to the ocean and more. 

The Mosaic Steps are off the beaten path from the typical tourist attractions and activities in San Francisco, but they are definitely a hidden gem! It was an incredible experience to admire and climb these steps and they were definitely worth seeing.
author: Brittany T.

description: Chilling here atb the top with the wind blowing mightily at my head. Feeling.accomplished. The steps are fairly easy and the view is awesome. Get your light without on over here. Hit the steps fast and hard to get that good burn. The heart of a champion folks. Weekend warrior...WAAAAAA
author: Robert F.

description:
These steps are an amazing sight to see and a great walk. We went on a slow day and I am so glad we had been walking before our journey out to the city because these steps are worth the trek up. 

Read the history of these steps before you just walk up them and take the time to look out at the view and don't forget to look down at each tile you can. It can be chilly at the top but it is worth it. 

Another breathtaking and worthwhile community art project worth seeing!
author: Tina S.

description:
This place is pretty cool and you definitely get a fantastic view from the stairs and down to the whole city. It's also an awesome place to watch the sunset! We came here just in time to watch the sunset and it was amazing! Parking is also pretty easy since the residential area isn't so packed and the streets are pretty wide.

Just a warning: the stairs are a work-out. It's definitely very steep and you will be tired by the time you get up there! It's definitely a nice view once you get up there though. It's also a very nice view up there, so it's definitely worth working out those leg muscles! 

The mosaic steps are also very nicely done. It's so pretty! I love that they included the names who probably participated in this project. Those who live by are so lucky! 

Hint: there is also another copy-cat stairs down the street! I don't know the exact location. But if you're facing upward to the stairs, keep walking down the street toward the left! It's probably like five minutes away. Keep walking until you see an intersection and turn left! It'll be on the right and that stairs will be going down to a different street. If you get lost, do ask whoever that may be around. They'll most likely will know what you're talking about. They're friendly people.

Overall, I definitely enjoyed visiting these two sets of stairs. Such pretty sight and definitely shows the community who put these stairs together. I highly recommend coming here for sunsets or just in general!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
Warning: Frequent DAYTIME auto burglaries!! 
Leave NOTHING in your car at this location.

Short Version:
The Tiled Steps area is heavily trolled by crews of thieves who prey on tourists and sightseers, smashing into their cars in broad daylight. Broken auto glass is everywhere.

Long Version:
The police and City know about it, the locals have posted warning signs, and it's been in the news (just google "Tiled Steps, neighbors fight back"). In spite of all the attention, car windows are smashed here almost every day. Here's why:

1. People don't bother to read the warning signs, and leave stuff in their cars.

2. People don't think it can happen to them, in broad daylight, in a residential area, in such a short window of time. So they leave stuff in their cars.

3. People try to hide stuff in the hatchback of their cars. These thieves are good at their job, and have been seen posing as students, tourists, etc. They see you putting stuff in the back, where the window is just as easy to break - and more expensive to fix.

4. San Francisco doesn't prosecute the criminals! Even when the police are able to catch someone, the thief is back on the street in no time thanks to lenient apathetic judges and District Attorney George "Glasscón" (co-author of the regretful Prop 47, which fueled the explosion of auto glass on SF streets). 

Fun Fact: San Francisco had 29,500 smash 'n' grabs in 2015, according to the DA. That's about 80 per day, and the Tiled Steps area is one of the worst hotspots.

If you decide to go anyway and you're unlucky enough to be a victim, please report the incident using the info on any of the 27 nearby warning signs, so that your crime statistic can be used to influence City policy in the future.
author: Ward E.

description: This is an amazing spot for pictures! The stairs are well maintained by the locals. You can totally see the pride this community takes in caring for these stairs!
author: Mee V.

description:
Sunday, 11:00 AM.

Quickie:
+ Artsy, cool
+ Clean

And then...?
Mosaic staircase that aggregate to a larger visual (though each layer has its own picture). Walk the stairs and a view of the Bay (Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge) awaits you at the top. Put this on your list to check out!
author: Chuck N.

description: My group of friends were exploring SF and this was one of the pit stop. We found parking pretty easily at the bottom of the steps. You definitely can't miss the entrance to this set of steps. I really enjoy the beautiful houses surrounding the steps and the flower and decors around the steps are nice attributes of the steps. There are always people on these steps so don't feel shy asking them to take a picture for you or your group. You can casually go up the steps or race up and go back down. Just remember, since you're already here, pay a visit to Grand View Park, which is located at the top of the steps. The park will give you a beautiful pano view of SF and neighboring cities on a clear sunny day.
author: Minh-An C.

description: I expected more from this place but really, it was just the tile steps. The designs were really pretty. The stairs were easy to step onto! Once I got up all the way to the top, i got to see the view of San Francisco. Breathtaking moment! It was definitely worth going up those stairs. Definitely a tourist attraction. The parking was really easy too.
author: Tilia L.

description:
"This place is like MOMA with Step Climber gym sets. " - Manabu M.*

"WORD." - Amy C.

*http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-16th-avenue-tiled-steps-project-san-francisco#hrid:MiUcZYju8R7sz4cSwHla9A
author: Amy C.

description: First time seeing these steps as a SF native, I feel ashamed to say.  Well I visit frequently but I haven't lived in the city for about 14 years, and a lot has changed in the past decade or so, some good, some bad.  This is one of the more positive changes.  I've heard about these stairs a few years ago and since we were in the sunset visiting my stepdad this past visit, I took my kids to go check the stairs out.  They were absolutely beautiful and the view from the top of the Sunset district and Ocean beach is amazing.  So glad we made time to see them!!
author: Rosie M.

description: Beautiful tiled steps. Great for pictures. Good exercise. When you get to the top, you get a great view of the Sunset area. Good to bring friends and visitors here!
author: Benita M.

description: GORGEOUS mosaic stairs that lead to an amazing 360 view of GORGEOUS San Francisco. A must-see that's not flooded with tourists. Loved it.
author: Elysse P.

description: Something special about this place. And the Idea behind it. I don't know, but this hasn't really become overly popular by tourist......Yet. I AM GLAD. These are the prettiest stairs ever. The design and tile are worth driver if you have done the twin peaks, and ocean beach. I had ice cream and sat and watched the sunset here. It's beautiful!
author: Michael R.

description:
I keep seeing people with pictures here and I knew it had to be one of my stops next time I was in the city. I forgot which bus it was, but it literally takes you pretty much right in front of the steps. What a treasure this is in the middle of the city! It's sooo pretty! And apparently a lot of other people thought the same as well because there was so many people there checking out the steps and taking pictures. I love the colors and details and the design that went into these steps! And I love how you start at the bottom of the sea and end up in the sky! 

Overall, I could go on and on about how amazing these tiled steps are, but just do yourself a huge favor and check it out for yourself. Major props to whoever worked on this!

Protrip: go when it's sunny out. Though it's still cloudy when it's overcast, it will sparkle more in the sunlight.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Set of awesome mosaic staircase winding up to Grand View Park! =) I first learned of this through Secret Stairs L.A.

It's a easy walk up (less than 80 stairs) with a neat celestial mosiac to look at... great views at the top. 

** tucked away in a residental area, so you'll be parking on the street** =)
author: Mimi C.

description: Beautiful and free attraction!  There are 2 sets of stairs, as mentioned by others.  It would be great for exercise early before crowds!
author: Tricia S.

description:
WARNING!!!
Frequent daytime car break-ins/windows smashed.   Do Not leave ANYTHING in your car or trunk!!!  
Prowlers in the area watching for you to leave.  Have someone stand guard at your car.
Tiled Steps Director
author: Alice X.

description:
It's dangerous at night but still beautiful. Hidden gem in SF, outside of town near the Sunset District. Dangerous in the sense that the steps are NOT lit up and if you don't have a flashlight, you'll fall...a long way down. It's also not near anyone. It's a residential neighborhood so while it looked like a safe area, I wouldn't want my girlfriend or daughter to go alone.

Walk up several hundred steps where each one is a unique piece of mosaic art. I took my kids. They marveled at the beauty. Once at the top, we had an incredible view of the city and the ocean. Highly recommended and free!
author: Ron S.

description:
THEIVES IN THE AREA!!!!!!!
Be careful when you park your car to visit the steps.
There are people that watch and observe tourists as they leave their car. Once the tourists are busy at the steps they break in to the car and steal whatever they can grab.

This happened to me. I was gone for 15 minutes and when I came back I found my rental car window smashed and my belongings were missing.
As I drove around I noticed other empty parking spaces with shattered glass on the floor.
According to SFPD, this is a common thing in this area because of the amount of unaware tourists always visiting the steps.

Be on the lookout, if you notice someone at the top or the bottom of the steps by themselves, not taking any pictures and are just observing people then most likely that person is the lookout while their friends break in to cars.
Hide your belongings, lock your doors, and try to avoid parking in an isolated area.

San Francisco is a shady city in disguise.
author: Mark M.

description:
I like incorporating stair workouts into my weekly routine. I used to run them once a week in Santa Monica, running with all the pretty people decked out in lululemon and designer sunglasses, powering up those glutes with the ocean right in front of you. 

Now in SF, more often than not I'm the only one on these stairs other than the occasional tourist and when there are other people they are decked out in sweaters and sweaters and maybe an occasional beanie. 

The workout is still great, though and the mosaic paints a pretty picture going up. I like that the last few sections show a sun and moon. Every time I get to that point my thighs are burning and I want to die, but I think of Khal Drogo and Daenerys tragic love and it gives me fire and purpose so I power up the last few steps and do a hoarse Dothraki scream at the end. 

Sometimes if I'm really feeling the fire I'll keep going because you'll find mysterious steps leading higher, shrouded in Poe-ish mist that'll take you to the top of a tree-hemmed hill where it'll drop 10 degrees colder and maybe even rain a little. 

Because the world remembers too. 

My moon and stars. 

Damn you Martin. 

It's a great workout.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
A beautifully intricate landmark in the Sunset District! Usually bustling with tourists, thses steps are a prime photography location either from the bottom or from the top. While from the top on 15th Ave the stairs don't appear vivid, from the bottom on Moraga, you can see the colorful entirety of it, and the closer you look at each tile as you walk along it, the more you will be astounded by the patterns and contributors. Try to come when it's not busy so you can appreciate everything about it!

Just walking on it too makes you feel special, as if you are being annointed a special opportunity to walk on it for finding it. And your prize? A broad view of Noriega st. and Western Sunset! Once at the top continue to Grand View Park, where the sight lives up to its name... :)
author: Kyrie S.

description:
Absolutely stunning and worth ever step. There are several flights of stairs, but it's a fairly easy climb, especially when you're stopping ever so often to admire the work done here. It's even better when you make it to the top and overlook the city!! 

The drive there is fairly easy and there's plenty of street parking. There were a few other tourists and an occasional runner/exercise-r. I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Annie T.

description: This is my first visit here. I went in the evening just after sunset. The details of the steps are probably better seen in daytime. However the view of the city and ocean is amazing at night. And finding parking is so much easier!! While many go in the daytime, I suggest going night time too. I can't wait to go back during the day to see the tiles.
author: Fiona E. M.

description: A great neighborhood attraction in San Francisco! Nestled in the hills of the Sunset, the tiled steps are actually a tourist attraction.  I was photographing a friend during an informal photo shoot, while we saw many tourists and locals stopping by for their own photo ops.  There were also others just trying to get their exercise in by going up and down.  The tiled steps are truly a work of art and when you look closely, you'll find there's so much detail in the individual tiles.  Once you get to the top, you can see views of the entire Sunset neighborhood and beyond.  You can see an aerial view of the Golden Gate Park separating the Sunset and the Richmond.  You can see all the way out to the bay and both of the bridges.  Worth checking out if you're in the area!  There's also another set of tiled steps on the other side that had less foot traffic.  Keep it a secret!
author: Liv A.

description: This is one of the coolest place in SF! I would come here again to take pictures of obviously the stairs but the view up top is also amazing!
author: Karen K.

description:
Fairly easy to get to the top if you're in moderate shape. I expected a burn but you'll need to go up a few times for that. I continued on after those stairs to another level and then followed some other wooden stairs to the top of the city. Amazing view. 
Sorry... About the stairs. Haha
Mainly there were people taking pictures and a couple girls that were running up and down for a workout. Worth the trip. Wasn't too busy, quickly  found parking.
author: Marcela M.

description: A small spot in a bustling neighborhood but captures the essence of San Francisco :) wonderful bay views , the bay breeze and a perfect location for pictures
author: Sai Kiran M.

description:
What a beautiful staircase!

There are just over 300 steps if you climb this staircase, as well as the one beyond up Turtle Hill.  The landscaping and the tile work on the main set of stairs is gorgeous.  Granted, if you go on the weekend, you're likely to encounter more pictures of people's behinds as they climb the stairs over the mosaics, but it's still a beautiful climb and a great view once you're at the top!
author: Jes G.

description:
The steps are cool.

The teens hanging out on them are not. 

Trying to get a photograph without people in the background is difficult, if not impossible. Especially when there are gaggles of high schoolers/people who are trying very hard to look attractive/preening themselves hoping for the "perfect" "instaworthy" picture. They will literally sit themselves on the steps for half an hour trying to get the perfect photo. 

You think I'm over exaggerating, but we went all the way up the steps. Went to the outlook. Hung out for ten-fifteen minutes and when we headed back down the same group of kids were still sitting there taking photos with their selfie stick.. 

We just wanted one photo without a teenager posing in the background, was that too much ask? (Can you tell I'm a little bitter?) 

Anyways... They lead up to this street, that if you continue going up, will lead you to another set of rickety, wooden steps that bring you to this GORGEOUS outlook. It has a great view of the city... It was also super duper crowded and windy when we went so I'd recommend bringing a jacket.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Beautiful steps! Definitely worth the trip out of the way to see this gem! 

My friend and I go lost trying to find them but once we did!! We just don't now want to leave! 

It was cold sunny and windy day in San Francisco! Making it they much memorable 

Once we got to the steps is like the wind disappeared and we enjoyed the view
author: Karla ..

description:
What a beautiful hidden gem! 

Came to check out this beauty during my recent trip to SF trip.  The beautiful mosaic made these steps so easy and enjoyable.  Once at the top you get a panoramic view of SF. It's breathtaking.
Come during the weekday and early to avoid the crowds. 

Snap away!!!!
author: Christine T.

description:
I have wanted to see these for SO LONG. I must've seen them on someone's phone or on pinterest at some point, but I've been to SF multiple times and never put the effort into actually seeing it. SO WORTH IT.

We decided to road-trip up there so I finally googled it and found it on Yelp/ bookmarked it. It was extremely easy to find and there weren't too many people around (i.e., managed to actually get pictures of the stairs, not just people walking up them). 

The stairs are so beautiful and it's obvious that a lot of work and love went into mosaicing them--I think tourists and locals alike would enjoy them. 

Check it out for yourself. See something unique and utterly beautiful, you won't regret it.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
Love the tile designs and how they lead to more steps with lovely trees and a lovely view. 

The fog and sprinkles made it an sf experience!
author: Susan K.

description:
Love love this place !! The tiles were soo beautiful ! I suggest coming here when the sun is setting when you reach the top, it's beautiful especially if you just want to come here with your significant other (: nice view of the city ! 

And at night time the light turn on and it's even more beautiful ! Good place to come to if you're visiting or if you wanted to work out also
author: Julie D.

description:
Neat! 

What a cool find this place is. This hidden gem is a beautiful staircase that has colorful tiles on the side that form a visually pleasing picture. It's not intended as a touristy spot, but it has become one. Weekdays are the most ideal times to visit. Smaller crowds = better picture and view. 

Definitely a unique find in the city. Worth stopping by if you're in the area. And great exercise, esp. after a fatty dinner @ San Tung.
author: Suji C.

description:
Another Work of Art!

How cool is it that there are about 50 of these tiled steps around San Francisco?  Pretty darned cool, if I do say so myself!  These are among our favorites, because the steps are awesome AND they're flanked by beautiful gardens.  What's not to like?!
author: Ted Q.

description:
This place is a beautiful hidden gem in SF that needs to be more exposed. When I was searching up this site, it seemed kinda interesting... I guess. But hear me out, pictures are not doing this place justice. 

The staircase is an amazing piece of art. Also, if you can, walk ALL the way up those stairs. It looks like a long way up, but the panaromic view of the city is absolutely breathtaking and well worth the walk up.
author: Edlyn W.

description:
Much props to the artists. They did an amazing job. Also thanks to all the Yelpers who added some good photos of the place. This is one of those hidden gems that make SF so great. 

Enjoy the view when not foggy :) 

Tip, watch the street cleaning times in this area when you park. If you see lots of cars on one side and your the only one on the other side find another parking spot.
author: T C.

description:
Have you ever wondered what it was like to walk upon a stairway, glittered with shimmering tiles, arranged in colorful patterns to create a visual simulation of Earth, sky, and sea? 

Well behold and search no further my dear friend, for the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps will fulfill your deepest void in finding such a masterpiece!

So what I love about San Francisco is the fact that there are many hidden treasures, this being one of them. Nestled within a neighborhood full of residential homes and wide streets, you wouldn't think you'd embark upon such a unique work of art. Over 300 local neighbors contributed in the making of this community based project!

While enjoying this colorful mosaic, you get to enjoy a full on aerobic workout of climbing 163 steps! After you reach the top, you have a pretty stunning view. The downside was that my calves were sore for 5 days straight after attempting such a feat. This is totally dependent upon your level of conditioning. Apparently, I am not so much.

The location might be slightly tricky to locate, but that's why we have GPS locked into our phones and cars these days. So, no excuses, ok? I recommend visiting this little piece of jewel here in SF!
author: Ann S.

description:
Viewed from below, the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps looked like a stairway to heaven. Each step riser was intricately decorated with colorful mosaic tiles. Seen together; however, they revealed a cohesive and continuous mural of artistic design.

In a way, each step riser epitomized the splendor of each unique day, while the elaborate scenes on the entire staircase represented the tableau of life that lies ahead. Like in life, as we climbed one step at a time, we gained a progressively better and better perspective of our world.

At the top of the stairs, we arrived at the aptly-named Grand View Park, with its divine panorama and godly sunset overlook. The small one acre park sat atop a rocky reddish-brown chert outcrop, and was crowned by a solitary bench shaded by a Monterey Cypress tree.  Resting on the bench, we admired the sweeping view and contemplated life's journey, on our own stairway to heaven.
author: Joe R.

description:
I've had these steps on my to-see list for so long. After getting a new camera, my bf and I decided to spend a day in the city to play around with it. So these steps were on my must-see list for that day. 

We went on a Sunday afternoon on a gorgeous sunny day in November, so we knew we wouldn't have the steps to ourselves. Parking wasn't bad at all (street parking, but we found a spot nearby pretty easily). I was pleasantly surprised that although there were quite a few people on the steps, we ended up getting some pretty great photo ops. It was kind of nice to have some others there too so that we could trade cameras to get good group shots rather than several selfie fails. I did, however, feel a little pressure to climb the steps somewhat quickly, because of the others who waited behind to get pics without tons of people in them.

The stairs really were beautiful, and it was awesome to be able to see them close up on the way up and then get the opportunity for other pics on the way down.
