So, I'm new to yelp (kind of -- my old account seems to have disappeared, but then I didn't reveiw anything for a long long time. :) ).
But, one of the reasons I wanted to sign back up was the Moraga Step. Such an awesome art project, and a wonderful hidden, off-the-tourist path gem of SF. IT's not an earth-shatteringly mind-blowing thing. But it's beautiful, creative, surprising, and totally worth the trek out to the Sunset. seriously. 

And the view from the top at Grand View park is magnificent!

just go. trust me (and the other 158 smart people who are telling you the same thing!)
author: Dustin B.

description:
On a clear day in San Francisco, the 16th Ave Tiled Steps Project is a great place to see panoramic views of the city. Located on Moraga between 16th and 17th Street, the 163 mosaic steps soar straight up to the base of Grand View Park (one of San Francisco's highest points). The steps paint a picture of the sea flowing into the sky. A colorful twist of water and sea life swirl up the steps to land with flowers, plants, birds, and frogs and ends with a beautiful sky with stars and even a massive sun.  

The project started as a community effort to beautify the steps and ended up a work of art known around the world. Started in 2003, the 16th Ave Tiled Steps Project along with hundreds of volunteers helped the vision become a reality. Artists Aileen Barr and Colette Crutcher created the unique design of the risers and over 300 community volunteers helped make the tiles and bring the project to life. 

The steps aren't only known for their beauty. Many locals enjoy using the 163 as a work-out or a place to sit and reflect. The steps are located in Golden Gate Heights, a quiet neighborhood in the Sunset. They are easy to reach by Muni or by car with ample parking.
author: Alice S.

description: A gorgeous set of  164 masterfully painted and designed tile steps with ample parking and friendly people. An easy hike up, and that's not the end. There are even more steps up to an amazing park in the hills that has a 360 panoramic view of the entire city. You can see every building in SF, it's awesome. Everything is free. Bring a light coat and a camera. Just pick up after your trash and don't throw your cigarettes everywhere, nasty smokers. Great hike for kids and dogs too, not overly strenuous.
author: Chuck N.

description: This is a really nice and artsy feature. The tiles make different designs when seen at different vantage points and provide a great view. Keep your little ones close to the handrails and watch out when taking pictures so you don't fall backwards off of the landings. There are A LOT of steps. We brought water and took it a little slow so our whole family ages 7-41 could make it up the 10+ flights. Once at the top of the stairs we crossed the winding streets and took the path and stairs up to Grand View Park. I would recommend doing both at once as it's very satisfying and you feel like you're on top of San Francisco. There was plenty of FREE street parking at the bottom and the top of the stairs. The locals are really kind and gracious so it pays to be courteous with your parking. It is definitely worth more than one visit. I'd like to see it on a rainy day.
author: Bart H.

description: Beautiful mosaic tiles laid on the steps and you can continue up to Grand View park for an even more amazing view of the city.
author: Karla N.

description: Went to SF recently and had to see these beautiful stairs for myself with some friends. What a walk! It's probably the best walk/hike ever! You get an amazing workout going up so many stairs just to see the stairs then once you're at the site you go up these insane steps covered in beautiful tiles. So beautiful and unique!  Loved going here,it's a great day time activity with family and friends. Also makes for great photos!
author: Khat S.

description: A must see. You will see amazing views once you get on the top. Don't be scared of the long stairs, it's worth the climb!
author: Cecelia W.

description: B-E-A-UTIFUL! It's so lovely to see artwork in San Francisco! A must see for locals and tourists.
author: Kristine K.

description:
We drove to visit the steps on a slightly overcast Sunday afternoon.  Parking at the bottom of the steps was easy and felt safe.  Being severally overweight I was worried that it might be a struggle to make it to the top, no such problem. It was a slow and easy climb to the top as I stopped and examined the different tiled steps and turned around to enjoy the wonderful view of the city, the Golden Gate Bridge and the ocean.  We went on up the next set of boring looking stairs and then were greeted with another semi daunting set of stairs.  Once again I'm glad I decided to climb these, because once again they were beyond easy.  The view at the top was of Golden Gate Park and much of the city.  

You will see tourists on this little walk, but you won't be crammed up against other people like Pier 39 and Union Square.  It's a great way to see something different in SF and get into some of the neighborhoods.
author: Amanda F.

description: Must see for locals and tourists a like. The stairs are so beautiful. Each step was hand tiled and each section of the stairs between the landings tell a different story. It does get pretty windy at the top though, so bring a jacket. And if you're lucky to come by on a clear day, the views at the top of the steps offer great views of Sunset, the ocean and the Marin Headlands.
author: Sarah L.

description:
In desperate wanting of my beloved Santa  Monica Stairs workout I found these stairs in the Sunset not far from my house.  They are absolutely gorgeous and with intricate tile work on each step.  The view is also breath taking and the succulents that line the stairs are beautiful.  Each set has a different theme with the highest steps depicting the sun and the lowest with oceanic scenes.

I'm not sure why this place isn't crowded with a slew of people working out but it's a great workout to run up and down the stairs.  Also if you continue upward at the top of the stairs you will hit Grand View Park which also has another set of wooden stairs and an amazing view.

Forget all those touristy spots in SF, check out these stairs, they are awesome.
author: Mylinh M.

description: A friend told me about these steps, they are amazing. Definitely go when you have time to stop and look at them in detail, and bring a camera, we must have taken 100 pictures at least. I was also very sick that day so walking up the stairs was not much fun but the view from the top was worth every ounce of energy!
author: Venus S.

description:
Miscolored and bad painted steps? Youre wrong! Iconic stairs and tiles which everyone takes pictures of and posts them on Facebook.

Run up them for a good work out or just stare at the stairs and keep walking.
author: Tim M.

description: Thank you Yelpsters for this awesome find!  We caught the sunset here on a beautiful day.  I love the mosaics and will definitely be back!  Where are the other steps though?  We were only able to find the one in the pictures.  A guy who lived in the neighborhood said there were some others nearby...
author: Lai T.

description: AMAZING! These were on my list of beauties in san francisco, I went on a freezing day that was also very foggy and it was still beautiful. The only thing is that now a lot of people know about it and you can't really be alone to truly admire the beauty without the people walking/running up it. It's also a great workout spot with a view that's completely worth it!
author: Nerwel Z.

description:
Lately, I've been finding that the gym really bores me.  Having to work out in an extremely stinky and stuffy environment has been such a turn off for me.  Moreover, the sight of overly wannabe macho guys attempting to bulk themselves up has further turned me off.  The gym has become more of a hang out. 

I love the Sunset District.  I can feel totally safe walking from street to street feeling completely alone and relaxed, yet at the same time very pumped up and excited.  Never once have I been more excited to work out.  The neighborhood steps in the Sunset have become my new passion and work out.  

During one of my morning walks, I was so happy to find the 16th Ave. and Moraga tiled steps.  I could walk these steps multiple times and not get bored.  They tiles are so beautiful and colorful, and the best part is that they are autographed by the local community and supporters that made this tiled steps project happen. 

It would be nice to have more funding and support to take over and bombard the whole Golden Gate Heights steps in the Sunset with tiles.

All I can is wow...Beautiful steps, leading to the most beautiful view.  On a clear day the Pacific Ocean, I can imagine is breathtaking.  On that particular day that I climbed, I was greeted by the typical S.F. fog...and yet in all of its miserable gloomy glory rolling into S.F, it was extremely beautiful to watch.
author: Cass J.

description: Gorgeous neighborhood art! Easy parking since its a neighborhood. Gorgeous view at the top. The steps are a bit steep.
author: Christina T.

description: Such a great hidden gem in SF! Take the stairs!!
author: Megan G.

description: Came here Saturday afternoon and there was plenty of parking. Lots of people taking pictures at the steps so I don't think its a great spot to workout if you're looking for a stair master. We brought Penny and she had fun running up the steps. There's 3 different types of stairs you take to get to the top where there is a bench placed right in the middle. Loved the panoramic view although its so windy, typical SF weather. Don't just leave after you reach the top, definitely walk around so you can get a better view of the city from a lower angle.
author: Amy G.

description:
Go on a clear day for awesome views of the water!
Even farther up are some wooden stairs. If you go right at the top of the tiled steps and up the concrete stairs to the next street, you will see them. You must go up these wooden stairs to get the best views. 
Cute neighborhood to run around in too!
author: Sara P.

description:
I've known about this staircase from an SF Yelp newsletter awhile back, and traveling along 19th Ave, you can see this up the hill on Moraga. But I finally got the chance to see this up close and personal. 

This project is such a magnificent piece of work. Every step, every tile is a part of this massive mosaic masterpiece. I'm so amazed how the artists know where to put what. It's so rad. Take time to walk up this staircase to see all of the details. It's not everyday you see a neighborhood restoration project as beautiful as this.
author: Diana C.

description: I had seen a photo of these steps before ever coming to California so it was exciting to see them in real life. Its a relatively easy hike if you can handle some cardio and steps. With each step you're rewarded with a prettier view than the step before. It all ends at the top with a panorama of the city. Dont be bummed if the weather is good when you're at the bottom and then you get to the top and fog rolls in and you cannot see anything - you're simply experiencing sf love. And it might disappear just as fast as it showed up. And its free!
author: Yolanda Y.

description:
It took me 3 years living in the Sunset to finally check these steps out, and all I can say is I regret not coming here sooner. 

The Tiled Steps Project is a gorgeous artistic sight to see and the view from the top of the steps is simply amazing. It's also quite a workout to go up and down the steps, but with the gorgeous tile steps to view as you climb up as well as a magnificent view of the city as you descend, this will be one workout you'll enjoy doing.

So whether it's to come here to workout in a wonderfully scenic place or just to come by and appreciate the artistic style of these steps, you owe it to yourself to at least swing by here once to come check it out. You're gonna like what you see; I guarantee it!
author: Gajan K.

description: The steps absolutely beautiful and very well kept. The place is kinda hard to find, with the twists and turns and hills. It was a short walk from the N Judah line. Too bad, i came on a cloudy day so i couldnt get a good view but needless to say, the steps are a sight in itself.
author: Angela L.

description:
If you're going to bust your ass humps to get up to Grand View Park, then you might as well make sure to kill your thighs so that your descent back down to the Avenues will be about as fast as gravity can take your loathsome body off of it's spaghetti legs, and bounce it down the enchanting and psychedelic mosaics of tile. 

On the other hand, if you're in the neighborhood to tackle this small wonder of San Franciscology, then you might as well take your time and check the view as you climb, then continue on up to the top, then from there, take on Grand View and have a sip of something sinister, maybe a bite of manchego (both of which you thoughtfully packed), and take in the light and the space, quite often brushed in fog. 

Whether or not the weather is nice, this is usually one of the nicer, and lesser-trafficked views in the city (a crap shoot on nice days though), the whole way up is an ascent up to heights that elevate you out from the gridded averageness of living in the Avenues, and really, a lovely perspective on an otherwise ho-hum part of town. Don't get me wrong, I loved living in the Sunset/Inner Sunset. Regardless, the 16th Ave/Moraga Steps really is a beautiful strip of bacon-on-MDMA-and-LSD. Just keep in mind that you'll need your strength reserves to come back down (always harder on wobbly legs. Trust me. I almost faceplanted at one point).

One thing: while the view is something to behold on any day, on the usual fog machine Sunset days (insert "the sun really did set on this neighborhood" joke), the face of these hills are great at picking up the wind and accelerating them up their facades. So unless you're as naturally insulated as a polar bears asshole, then bundle up a touch.
author: Roy M.

description:
Best & prettiest stairs in the city!

My friend & I usually sprint up these stairs about 5 times each time we come here. Amazing view of the city at the top. And very clean stairs! Great workout. 

And there's always parking which is a plus.
author: Cara N.

description:
One of my favorite views of the city. Particularly due to the lack of tourists up there. 

'Nuff said.
author: Kori M.

description:
So cool looking up at the art, then you reach the top and realize, they're just normal looking steps with an incredible Golden Gate Heights view!

It's pure awesomeness to do these steps a handful of times up and down to keep your heart happy and your soul inspired.
author: Athena S.

description: A lovely, hidden spot that's worth the visit. Slow down and take a moment to look at the steps from far away and up close. The overall mosaic is gorgeous and the details up close are heartwarming. You can see so much of the community's heart and soul in the names and little pieces of themselves they've left behind. Make sure to take a look out from the top too, the cityscape is really nice.
author: Grace T.

description:
Likes: Beautiful mosaic tiles of the ocean and swirls make a cool piece of art seen from the bottom of the steps.  It's a pretty place to take pictures and get a little exercise while you're there :)  Plus there's a great view from the top.

Dislikes: That's pretty much the only thing there.
author: Karen M.

description:
Went on a clear beautiful day and must say, its breathtaking! Starting from the climb up through the beautiful Sunset neighborhood in 16th Ave and Moraga, the most beautiful mosaic artwork up the stairs , to the peak of the little hill which gives the perfect view of SF from Ocean beach to Downtown skyline, everything's just so beautiful!

To watch the sunset this is the most romantic place in SF! Maybe a small picnic or wine will make the day even more perfect! Must always carry a jacket as its windy at the top. 

The short hike through the mosaic stairs is definitely a must see in SF. Colorful artwork in the stairs is so much fun! Also unlike other touristy viewpoints like Twin peaks, here one get to enjoy a more serene atmosphere to take in the view.
author: Payal B.

description: I remember when they were still working on this flight of stairs, and when it was finally finished, i fell in love! This place is incredibly  breathtaking and walking up all those steps is worth it(: If you do decide to continue walking, there is another flight of stairs that leads you to Hawk hill/ Grand view park. Hawk hill (in my opinion) is 10 times better than Twin Peaks! There's a small bench there, you can sit and enjoy the view with your buds or your  partner!
author: Tracy V.

description: Really nice although it did take a bit of work to get to. Kind of at a random place. A lot of people use these steps to work out. I would too but its kind of far from where I live. It leads to these additional steps where you end up on top of this hill that overlooks the city. Its cold up there and only one bench that was taken by this couple.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I'm so proud to live around the corner from this beautiful piece of San Francisco!  The only thing more beautiful than the steps themselves is the view from the top ... and definitely make sure you go to the right once you reach the top and take the wooden staircase to the top of Grand View Park.  That is one of the most beautiful views in San Francisco.  You can see Downtown San Francisco, as well as Mt. Sutro, The San Francisco Bay, Golden Gate Bridge, Marin Headlands and every bit of Northern and Western San Francisco plus the Pacific Ocean.

Now let me counter some things that I've read by other people who have posted here.  I would like to dispel a misnomer.  These steps are not in The Sunset.  They are in Golden Gate Heights!!  Though the Sunset is only three blocks west, it's an entirely different world from here.  These steps are a great source of pride for Golden Gate Heights and the Inner Sunset.  This project was overseen by and is maintained in large part by the Golden Gate Height Neighborhood Association. Amongst other foundations.  Check out: http://www.tiledsteps.org/

Next, let me correct those who say you need to rent a car to get here because it's not public transportation accessible.  That's completely untrue.  You can take the N Judah Muni Train to 16th Avenue and walk three blocks South to the stairs (the first set of stairs you encounter will not be the tiled stairs, but you will need to climb those to get to the tiled stairs).  Or you can Take the N Judah Muni Train to 9th Avenue & Judah, then catch the 66 bus that will drop you off right in front of the steps!  

Finally, for those who say there is a shortage of clear weather here in which to see the great view. The foggy season is the summer only.  The rest of the year the weather here is the same as the rest of The City.  So if you are a enthusiast of the outdoors or a hiker or a stairway climber or a view seeker, get out here to Golden Gate Heights and climb these beauties to enjoy the view from Grand View Park.  

Afterwards, make your way to our Inner Sunset shopping district on Irving (centered around 9th Avenue) for some great restaurant choices near Lincoln Blvd and the entrance to beautiful Golden Gate Park's museums, Botanical Gardens, Japanese Tea Garden and Conservatory of Flowers.  Make a day of it!!
author: Daniel S.

description: I agree this is really a labor of love:  love of community, dedication to love ones, and love of neighborhood.  If the sun hits it right, you can the see the reflection of the sky from the stairs.  Half way up the view is magnificent.  How I love San Francisco!  After these stairs, just cross the street and you spot another set of stairs - "non-pretty" steps and you will get the bigger, more magnificent view.  I feel like I'm on top of San Francisco.
author: Helen L.

description:
After you savor the heart warming colorful view of the whole staircase and the surrounding make sure to notice the details of the artwork in every step while you climb to the top. You took the effort to go all the way here, so go to the top of the hill now!
At the end of the colorful stairs, to your right you'll see another small and unappealing concrete staircase. Climb it and you'll find yourself in the 15th ave. at the bottom of grand view park. And grand view it is. All that left to do is to take the wood staircase to the top of the hill and be rewarded by a 360 degrees of magnificent views.
The top of the hill is high and exposed. It is windy and cold so, don't come on a windy day and bring a jacket/coat at any day. I will do it again and again, I want to see the view in a different light, and weather conditions.
I also recommend to take a walk/drive in the lovely neighborhood with its beautiful houses.
author: Stephanie A.

description: My niece and nephew, as obsessed as they are about all things fish/ocean/aquarium, love these steps.  The way to go is up so you can view all the artwork as you climb (if you go down you'll have to keep turning around to see it).  I especially like all the succulents planted at the bottom.  Beautiful and reminiscent of underwater plants and coral.  Looks great with all the fish tiles.
author: Jean K.

description:
After a filling brunch at Park Chow, my boyfriend and I walked from the Inner Sunset up to 16th & Moraga to get up to these stairs. The walk through the neighborhood in and of itself is pretty cool but once at the stairs, WOW. The view from top to bottom of the steps is beautiful and each section has a different motif that all blends in to the total design. The detail is amazing and so are the views as you hike up. Stop at each landing and turn around to see views of the Ocean, the Sunset and Golden Gate Park. What a great neighborhood project and worth the trek for sure.
Once at the top you can go a little further and head up to Grand View Park. The views there are equally amazing. We went on a windy, cold day in early November and although the sun wasn't out, the skies were clear. It was pretty cool being able to see all of Golden Gate Park, the division of the Sunset and Richmond and then all the way out to the Pacific. 
Bundle up, make sure you've had a snack and take this (mini) hike for rewarding views, a slight workout and some amazing homes along the way.
author: Jennifer N.

description: A must see for tourists and residents alike. Not difficult to find & worth the travel time.  You can loop in a day trip to the Beach and GG park.
author: Hiromi N.

description: Definitely a hidden gem. Love the succulent garden that is planted at the base. At the top of the mural staircase you can walk across the street and continue to climb more stairs for an even more breathtaking view of the city. Great for out of towners. Gets pretty windy at the top, so bring a warm jacket! And for once, parking is easy.
author: Lisa H.

description: I would come back here again. Beautiful unique tiled steps and a good workout.
author: Grace C.

description: What an awesome "gem" of a view today. It was warm and balmy. Fantastic view of the ocean. It's not crowded and you can find parking! Score!  Thanks Piggy.
author: Jboogie L.

description: TOURIST SPOT: Discovered this place on a friend's facebook page. We drove to this area especially for the stairs. It was sprinkling that day, so it wasn't very crowded. Usually there are locals running up and down with their dogs for exercise. The view is breath-taking at the top, so take a moment to let it in. If you cannot walk up the stairs, you can drive to the top and experience the view that way. We didn't spend more than 15 minutes here, but took some pictures and left. There are tons of touristy place sto visit in SF and this is definitely one of them. Make sure to read the plaque at the bottom.
author: Ameera D.

description:
Best view of SF!
I went up with my friend and she said this is local stuff... and pretty cool so we went up. 
Steps are very cool, variant colors and it's ok steep. I wouldn't really recommend for kids because it can be worse as you go up. especially to another step up to see the best views of SF.

Its a really good place to just hang, and just to see the tiles. 
the tiles are really amazing.
author: Rachel H.

description:
What a beautiful project by artists Colette Crutcher & Aileen Barr done back in 2005. 

2005? Why am I only seeing this today?) 

This type of beautification project is a great example of what neighborhoods can do to change their environment to look more positive, inviting and fun visit. 

Will add this stop to our typical itinerary for out-of-town visitors of this great city. I hear the place is nice at night too -- one more thing to check out.
author: Rupert W.

description:
What a cool idea for a community project! I found the Tiled Steps Project initially while surfing through the local flavour listings and after reading some of the reviews, decided I was going to set out to find these colourful mosaics.

It was a long hike from where I was housed downtown, but my route on my Yelp map didn't lead me astray. It just took me awhile to get there. There were a great many hills that I had to walk up. And that was to the bottom of the stairs. I'd recommend driving or hopping a bus to this point.

At any rate, the stairs are quite impressive. There's a plaque at the bottom saying that it was a community beautification initiative by the neighbourhood funded by a grant from the City. What a wonderful idea! Thanks for doing this San Francisconites. I thoroughly enjoyed walking up your beautiful stairs and reading some of the names of the families and businesses who helped tile them.
author: Wendy P.

description: The walk up these stairs is tiring but worth it. Amazing view and the art on the steps are so beautiful!!
author: Angela L.

description:
Beautiful steps, beautiful view. 

After walking up all 163 steps you get a view of the city you normally can't get. I love it! It's a peaceful neighborhood with plenty of parking. 

Definitely make it out here- it's well worth it!
author: Christine A.

description:
Dear adolescent guys, if you want a cheap (FREEEEE) cute date, take her here. Climb to the top together, profess your love, and kiss her. 

You're a lucky bastard if that girl hasn't been here before. 

I'll need to come visit at night sometime.
author: Liana L.

description:
When I first moved to the sunset I checked out this spot. Shot some pics, soaked in the view and appreciated the artwork. 

+ Tiles are beautiful and colorful. I have never seen a mural like this before. 

+ Good place to get your workout in, rather than staring at any other flight of stairs. 

Check it out while the weather is still nice and clear!!
author: Julia D.

description: My favorite spot in the 'hood! A true hidden gem of Inner Sunset.
author: Rabab M.

description:
These steps are crazy cool! And crazy steep, phew! 

My husband and I had been hauling ass to all the sites in San Fran during our short not-even-three-day stay, and I'm so glad we made it to see the tiled steps! 

It's quite a steep hike up the steps, but not difficult. View from the top is nice, but not incredible. Just rooftops, mainly. 

Go see them! :)
author: Carrie O.

description: i would say that navigating around san francisco is quite interesting, the fun is finding what buses to transfer to get to your destination, the steps is quite unique and interesting as it is decorated with many types of objects along with the sponsors names engraved on the stones, once you get to the top, you get to see the neighborhood area of san franscisco, we went there late april and it was really foggy up there, like a floating city in the sky, you would not want to go to the end of the block because you feel like you will fall into an abyss, for those exploring SF, please wear comfortable shoes as there are lots of hills everywhere, if you don't believe me, try it and you will be huffing and puffing regardless of the shape you are in because we are not accustomed to walking hilly areas on a daily basis
author: Bakchun K.

description: I found these tiled steps on yelp a week or so our San Fran vacation and it wasn't a priority at first but then we had a free day and I said something and my family and I went. IT WAS STUNNING. the stairs are beautiful and view from the top is absolutely amazing.  You could see everything. It would be even better if you could go on a day with minimum fog. Or at night you'd be able to see the city lights. Definitely a 10/10 would recommend. I was very happy and it's totally somewhere I would want to go back to!
author: Megan D.

description: The intrinsic artwork of the the tiled steps was stunning.  Beautiful detail with different settings.  I definitely recommend adding this to your itinerary when visiting.  The view from the top is so rewarding.   (You can not see the tiles from the top, you must enjoy them from going up the steps)
author: Tina E.

description: The most beautiful steps I have ever gazed upon in my life. Seriously walk up them and just take in the artistic masterpiece, and then keep walking up to Grand View Park and take in the gorgeous views of the city, assuming there is no fog of course. These steps are by far one of my favorite city gems. Thank you to all who took the time to put it together. Bravo!
author: Zak P.

description:
We spent a few days in SF this past week and I bookmarked these steps on our "To-see" list.  I didn't know what to expect, at first. It was actually underwhelming when we drove by at first. I was like, "That's it?". But as I got closer to the steps and marveled their intricacy, I realized that these steps were a lot more meaningful, than anything.  I admire how they allowed people to donate a tile, how one's name and contribution will be forever memorialized in such an awesome project that celebrates community.

In the brief time we were there, people came and went, sat at the top of the stairs and looked out toward the city, walked up and down for exercise. In a city where it is always bustling, loud, and even chaotic, this is a place of tranquility.
author: Marylan S.

description: Went to this place on a clear day.  The steps are pretty easy to climb.  They're not giant steps just many slightly shorter than average steps and they were really fun walking up seeing which businesses donated.  We continued up to the top of the mountain that awaited a gorgeous view of the city that I had never seen before.   Ocean to your left, golden gate park in the front, and the downtown skyline to your right.  Gorgeous!  Not a place to stay for too long though because there's only one park bench at the top and many people coming and going.
author: Sheila E.

description: Fantastic hidden gem in the city! The view from top is gorgeous.  I went on a Saturday and only the locals were there, exercising on the steps and enjoying the view.
author: Brittany P.

description: Such a beautiful little part of the city. It's one of those places you might want to see if you are looking for something easy, quick, and when the weather is nice. It was a gorgeously clear Saturday and we drove out here for what I thought would be a hike, but it's definitely not a hike - the stairs are pretty short and so are the other stairs that go up to Grand View Park. But it's a great little walk, I'd say. And you have a gorgeous view of the city and water. If you are not a frequent visitor to the Sunset area, I'd drive out here to explore the area, have lunch, and maybe head to the park afterwards if you want more outdoors. But for a quick excursion, it's a unique little trek.
author: Veronica H.

description: My friend took me here one time. It is a nice staircase where you just walk up and down. You can see a lovely view of the sunset district and if you are not afraid of heights. My friend took some photos here.
author: Serena Z.

description: So pretty!! Free parking and a sf gem! You can work out on these steps and the view of the stairs going up is great. The little fishes have the donors names :)
author: Diane S.

description: Awesome, amazing mosaic work of art!  I remembered many, many years ago when these steps were just old concrete steps.  I applause for the work put into making these stairs a hidden gem in the Sunset.
author: Patrick C.

description: Beautiful!! So worth a visit! These steps are tucked away in a residential area of the Sunset district. We were staying in a vacation rental house several blocks away and walked over. Once you get to the top of the tiled steps, I recommend going a little farther and higher to get to the little park that gives you a great view of the city below.
author: A. H.

description: Gorgeous steps with a gorgeous view at the top. Definitely worth a look. And people keep this place neat and tidy too! When we went, there was a community service group weeding and picking up trash around the steps. The neighborhood is lovely too, they have some nice houses and stuff. A great place for a walk and if you appreciate art!
author: Eugi H.

description: Definitely worth the hike and the chill! The stair itself is gorgeous, and the succulents and other plants alongside add to it's charm.
author: Sophie B.

description: And after you make it to the top of the steps, continue to the right about 200-300 feet to find the stairs to take you to the top of the hill for truly a grand view of both the ocean and the peninsula. Even though your thigh muscles and calves may disagree, you'll thank yourself for making the effort once you get to the top. Trust me.
author: Paul F.

description: One of my favorite moments in SF was at this place. The view is awesome and the hike to the top is amazing. It was tourist free(besides us) and seem like a place were locals would go to enjoy the view.
author: M W.

description: The stairs are amazing on both sides of the hill. And you can't beat the views from the park at the top. Not to be missed.
author: Gary M.

description: Absolutely gorgeous.  Worth a visit.  Be sure to take the masterpiece in as an entire image, landing by landing, and as each individual step.  The thought and craftsmanship that went into this is spectacular and worth spending some time to admire.  The views from the top of the staircase are incredible and it's nice to get a bit of exercise walking up.  Maybe even two or three times.  So glad I was able to visit and look forward to coming back on my next trip to SF.
author: Dania R.

description: Wow. Totally blown away at the craftsmanship that went into this truly BEAUTIFUL artistic tile work. Awesome colors and shapes! Truly a masterpiece!
author: Jesse G.

description:
The steps themselves are located at the corner of 16th Avenue and Moraga, in the heart of Golden Gate Heights, and what a heart it is.  Beautiful homes overlooking the city, freshly paved roads lacing through the hills. Having ridden my bike from the Richmond District, across Golden Gate Park and through the inner Sunset; I eventually gave up and pushed my bike up the hills between 19th to Irving to Judah to Kirkham.  Soon, I gave that up to, and chained my bike at 15th & Kirkham, and walked to 16th & Moraga.  I mention all of this, as a suggestion to take the #28 bus, the N line or simply drive, there's tons of parking and the bus lets you off at the steps.

The steps are amazing; all 163 of them.  You will want to stroll and gander; read and contemplate the stories and creation of this staircase.  At the top; don't turn around yet.  There is more, and that more is well worth it.  But a couple of precautions.  The 'more' is not only cold, but very windy.  And here is where I want to help prepare those many peeps visiting our fair city by the Bay; this is NOT Southern California, awash in tan-lines and bleach blondes.  This is San Francisco, a city with a chill vibe, in more ways than one.  Always carry a jacket and a hat; no matter the day of the week, the time of the year-or for that matter, the time of the day.  In San Francisco, saying you don't look good in a hat, is like you saying you don't look good in shoes.  My only complaint is, so many hats, yet I have only one head. Staying true to my mantra of always supporting indie artisans, I go to Berkeley and buy my hats from the fantabulous Grace Love.  I have in fact, bought several of varying colors.  They are all handmade with natural fibers and extra love added.  I have an affinity for Grace, as we are both birds of a feather.  She is a single parent, who pays $248.00 per year, to set up and sell her handmade wares on Telegraph Avenue in Berkeley. Check out her cool designs here: http://www.crochetnlove.com/ With hat and jacket, you are now ready to tackle the next set of steps, which will deliver you to Grand View Park. A most fitting name for a most grand view.

This final set of 143 wooden steps, gently slope and meander to the top of the hill. There are benches along the way, with plaques and notes.  The wind is substantially more fierce here and you will need your hat, but once you are there, the view is spectacular.  There is a bench at the top, where you can sit and watch the fog gently roll in and envelop the city.  Or on a clear day, the sun glints off rooftops in the distance.  Either way, the view is breath taking. And much like the hat, which has become a sort of art for me, so does this city seem to be.

For  a more in depth review, including history and photos, please visit our site at www.tnbta.com
Cheers! Heather
author: Heather J.

description: A friend recommended i took my sister (out of towner) to visit this place / kill time between meals ... And it was pretty fun! It was really pretty but I did enjoy the panoramic  view of SF from the top of the golden view park itself better. We took a touristy picture of with the stairs and left. We socal people aren't exactly fans of driving up steep streets and parking on rolling hills..
author: Jessica K.

description: A beautiful view of San Francisco in a very non-touristy area.  Reminded me of Parc Guell in Barcelona. :)
author: Janina R.

description: Truly gorgeous...though a bit hard to find.  Don't be fooled..the park has an astounding view, but not related to the tiled stairs.  If you have time to do both, and make sure that you spend as much time looking at the flora and fauna next to the stairs and trail as you to the stairs and view.
author: Matt B.

description:
This is the one tourist spot that tourists don't travel to.

If you don't have a rental car it's almost impossible to get here since the buses out here are so inconsistant.

But if you do make it out, oh is it worth it!!!

We didn't know exactly where it was so we ended up climbing the giant hill on the other side of these steps.

One of the best accidents we made our whole trip.

It's a giant hill that over looks the city with the ocean in the back ground.  We got here just in time for the sunset.  We were running late and wanted to see it from Twin Peaks but I must say this random hill gave me the sunset I dreamed of.

It was a beautiful sight and best thing yet we were like one of the only people there besides the residents of the neighborhood themselves.

We politely asked the residents, "where are the tiled steps?"

It was just on the other side of the hill.

We got to them and I peaked over and jumped up and down in excitement since we had finally made it.

We started at the top so it was a mystery as we walked down them and watched each section one at a time.

For anyone this is the way to go.  Because you get a little and then you get to the bottom and your mouth just totally drops.

This was the highlight of my trip.

It was freezing outside but after we found this my body was reenergized!!!

Anyone coming to San Fran, make it out to this uncommon tourist spot.  It will be worth the trouble, I swear!!!
author: David N.

description: I bookmarked this place in yelp 2 years ago and finally decided last month to just GO! I'm so glad I took the time out of my day to go. As the pictures here show you, this place is beautiful and breathtaking. Just don't rush and make sure to enjoy every detail of this masterpiece since each piece of tile was planned and not placed by accident. Have fun.
author: Vivian L.

description: The simple pleasures you find in your neighborhood=priceless! These stairs are not only beautifully tiled, but they are a great workout. I brought my sister's who were visiting and we climbed our way to the sky. It doesn't end there, continue up the next two staircases to reach an incredible view of the city. This is one of the many reasons I love San Francisco. Hidden gem.
author: Jackie B.

description: These stairs are a must climb for tourists and locals alike. The steps are as beautiful up close as they are from father away. Once you climb to the top you can stop off at grand view park and take in one of the best views in the city.
author: Nicole G.

description: Gorgeous. I was lucky enough to see this during the golden hour (first and last hour of sunlight) and I highly recommend it. If you decide to climb them, note the exquisite details on each step. Keep climbing, take the wooden stairs (look right), climb, climb until you're on top of Grand View Park. Enjoy.
author: Yan E.

description: a must check out place when you're in the city. prepare to climb this 150+ stairs to the top to see the view.
author: Stacey P.

description:
The only reason to rent a car when you are in San Francisco is to see these gorgeous steps. Nice place to visit after the museums in Golden Gate Park are closed. Beautiful landscaping with California native plants, including a couple of huge fremontodendrons.

Keep walking up after you have gotten to the top of the tiled steps. There are wooden steps up to Grand View Park. It has amazing views of Mt Sutro and the city, as well as a lovely collection of sand dune/chert  based California native plants.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_View_Park
author: Vena V.

description: As a long time Sunset resident I've seen these steps a million times but have never bothered to stop. Sad, I know. I finally decided to stop by with friends for a quick workout. The steps are amazing! The tiles are colorful and beautifully laid out. When you get to the top of the steps you get an incredible view out to ocean beach on a clear day. If you walk up further you will reach Grand View Park and there you will get an even more incredible view!
author: Adelina W.

description: These stairs are beautiful and well-done. I'm lucky to live close to them and I take out-of-town visitors to the steps for a quick, great view of the city. We always love the walk up.
author: Angie W.

description:
A colleague had told me about this.  He'd sought it out on a recent trip because his wife had started doing mosaics.  And when I was in San Francisco, my cousin told me that her childhood friend's mother was one of the artists behind it.  So taking that as some kind of tourist's kismet (that, and the fact that it was by a yarn shop I was hoping to check out), I ventured way out into Sunset to go see the steps.
It's out of the way, and a really long bus ride from most of the city, but it's really beautiful when you get there.  I'm sure it'd be a lot easier to see if you were driving, so much like avoiding taking the stairs at Coit, you'll be in better luck if you have a car.
When I went there it was a weekday at daytime, so I pretty much had the steps to myself.  I spent a bunch of time on the bottom taking pictures, and then wandered up sections of the steps, pausing now and then to take a few more shots.  (And, who am I kidding?  Maybe to catch my breath a little, too?)  There are some really cute details in the steps, and the effect is really remarkable - even better in person than in pictures!  And once you get to the top of the steps, not only do you feel like a total rockstar, but you're greeted with a great view of the Bay.  Win win!
author: Leigh G.

description:
BEAUTIFUL!!!  This area is a treasure is San Francisco.  My jogging buddy and I started at Hawk Hill Park at 14th & Rivera, then Sunset Heights Park, on to Grand View Park and ended at the Mosaic Stairway to Heaven.  What a treat!  It wonderful examining each section, looking at the details of the tiles and get a grand view at the very bottom.  

You also get wonderful views of the city from the chain of parks in the surrounding area.  Plus, we did see a hawk flying above.  This spot really is like a "secret" spot, didn't see any tourists at all.
author: Teresa C.

description: I'm a super fan of this breath taking place, it's so beautiful! I took lots of pictures :) I kind of give up on having random people in my "shot" lol it's definitely a workout up those steps, especially if you do it a few times
author: Melinda F.

description: Not sure if it's worth your time to go out of your way here, and I didn't bother to walk to the top of the steps, but the steps are beautiful nonetheless. The neighborhood its in is very quaint and not too far from the Golden Gate Park.
author: Lemon C.

description:
16th Avenue Tiled Steps, why must you send me mixed signals?

Romantic: Observing the way the moon lights up each tiled piece of your mosaic.  Slowly walking up each step, concentrating on the shimmering colors, and becoming lost in the beautiful art.  Finally arriving at the top, looking over the Sunset district and out toward the ocean.  Peaceful and quiet, you give me an opportunity for silent meditation and appreciation of life.

UnRomantic: Waking up the next morning unable to move my legs, because you showed me that I'm more out of shape than I had thought.  Realizing it doesn't matter how cute my outfit is, because people notice me taking tiny, painful steps and wonder why I'm walking like a duck.
author: Janney B.

description:
A groovy case of stairs not for the faint of consciousness, this glittering array of mirror and tile mosaic stretches from base to ledge proper of Grand View park... a striking assemblage of the peoples' art visible only from one direction.  

This was a kind addition to a dreary climb and cleverly reminds the walker that art in SF can pop up anywhere in unexpected places, lying in wait to stimulate the senses like a transient Bush Man.  

Running up or down its worth a pause, to enjoy the view for those who like it both ways.  These stairs have momentum that will continue to build, so be glad you too, were there at the beginning.
author: Jim W.

description:
Isn't it lovely?

Inspired by Santa Teresa Steps, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, this 163 Mosaic panels were done by the local artists and neighbors, working together with tilesetters and fundraisers.

I got an opportunity to finally see this after driving by so many times, initially i thought from afar someone had "tagged it" but it turned out to be tiles. I remember on a nice sunny day, you could see the ocean from the top. i wish they could do more with the gardening and some water sprinkling system. It would be nice to see a nice flower observatory here.

Tax Deductible Donations for Maintenance Fund thru Golden Gate Heights Neighborhood Association.  www.gghna.org

Please help donate to keep this alive for many generations to come.
author: Stanley K.

description: I thank yahoo for telling me about this. Before that article, I would have never known about this and would have left San francisco without seeing this beautiful work of art. The hike itself wasn't exhausting, but it did give me quite a workout.
author: Steven T.

description:
So, I saw a photo of these stairs at the gift shop at Fort Point under Golden Gate Bridge, & decided that I HAD to go check these out!

I found a book called Stairway Walks in San Francisco & I made this into urban hike #2 with my friend who "doesn't hike."  

So, this all began when a young woman who lived in Rio de Janeiro & saw from her apartment window the Santa Teresa decorative stairway thought it would be wonderful if the concrete stairway she saw from her San Francisco window would sing with colors instead of nondescript grey.  The famous Scala steps in Caltagirone, Italy was one source of inspiration for this neighborhood project.  The designers are local mosaic artists, Collette Crutcher & Aileen Barr.  So, on August 27, 2005, the newly designed stairway was dedicated.  Children call it "the magic stairway."  This info is all from the book mentioned above.  A walker quoted in the book counted 162 steps and a total height of 100 feet.

The stairway is indeed magical & amazingly beautiful!  The view from them is rather nice too.  As you can see from my profile, I went nuts & took lots of photos (that's not all of them, either).  
 
We easily found parking on Moraga, right down the hill from the stairs.  This is where we started our walk, by going up the stairs, & from there around the neighborhood, up & down several other non-decorated stairways, around Golden Gate Heights Park, and Grand View Park.  When we were ascending the mosaic stairs at the beginning of our walk, we encountered a woman who was sitting halfway up, enjoying a snack & the view.  Her daughter & dog had already made it up to the top & were sitting up there enjoying the view.

I wish I lived near here so I could come admire & use these steps more often!
author: Linda T.

description: OMG!  The pics do not even begin to do this work of art justice!!  WOW!  When you see it in person you realze the amount of time and effort that went into this project and it is absolutely BREATHTAKING!!  Job well done doesn't even begin to express my thanks!  I drove from Sacramento to see this and it was worth every mile, every mnute!
author: Barbara P.

description: I love how I am still discovering the most fabulous things in SF to be wowed by and to to wow friends and family with.  Climb to the top of the hill for a breathtaking view.
author: Ash A.

description: Came here on a cloudy day, so will definitely need to re-visit (it's conveniently just a walk from the muni 28).  Really gorgeous artwork, and it's also worth to go to the park just behind it.
author: Lily N.

description: If you're ever looking for a spot to just sit and stare off into the ocean in the far off distance, this is the place for you. Look no farther. The view on top of this hill is just awesome. What you can see is from the top of the hill is Moraga street running all the way to Ocean Beach. The titled steps is another great reason to visit these stairs. There's different titles making up the sun, stars, and the moon. Another plus is it's a good stair workout place to hit.
author: Steven B.

description: been in the neighborhood for awhile and i like to walk up the stairs on a clear day the view is amazing when it's nice out...Which is rare in the sunset dist. mostly foggy lolz
author: jonathan h.

description: You will be charmed by the mosaic steps and their colorful, thoughtful details.  You will be awed by the spectacular view of the city, ocean and Marin.  What a gem.
author: Ivan C.

description:
I have become obsessed with mosaics.  I've only taken 2 classes, but ask anyone who knows me....whenever I come across tiling, glass, or any other type of mosaic pattern, I go nuts.
So, you can imagine what occurred when I happened upon these stairs.  They are absolutely beautiful and every time I go, I stand at the bottom and stare up in awe.  I love the progression and the way the ocean blends into the sky and bright sun.  It is honestly one of the most amazing pieces of art in the city, in my humble opinion....
Now, if only me and my laziness would climb up and down those stairs...
author: Jessica L.

description: ahh this place is awesome!! the art mosaic is so pretty and the view amazing!!  It is one of San Francisco's hidden treasures indeed...we kept walking after this colorful stairs towards the Grand View park and got even more amazed!  wonderful day, wonderful hike, and awesome view!!!
author: Elc C.

description:
If you're not afraid of heights (unlike moi, going up is less likely to give me palpitations than going down) and are in the mood for exploring the city, a hike up these steps is an awesome treat.  There are 163 mosaic panels starting with ocean/fish/shellfish tiles at the bottom and graduating to plants, sky and the sun at the top of the stairs.  The tiles are colorful and picturesque. There are sturdy handrails on both sides of the steep staircase.  A requirement for me to climb. 

About 300 neighbors created this with over 220 of them donating to sponsor the tiles (they get their names and businesses engraved on the tiles), including Arizimendi Bakery, The steps were inaugurated in 8/05.  There's a plaque at the bottom of the steps listing the names of major individuals involved with the undertaking of the project.

When you get to the top, there is another non-mosaic steep staircase.  If you venture up that, you get to Granview Park (also known as Turtle Hill) where you can get a 360 degrees view of SF.  On a clear day, you can see forever......
author: Ry T.

description: Out of breathness and butt cramps are sure to happen as I reach the top but its so damn beautiful. Have yet to see it on a clear sunny day. There seems to be a shortage of those here! Each tile is beautiful in itself but as you go up the design flows together. But wait there's more. Your not done yet. Cross the street and go up a couple more stair cases and your in a misty, foggy oasis of a park. Feels like your on top of the world. The views must be amazing on a clear day but again that damn sun shortage here. If your lookin for some exercise or just need to clear your head check it out.
author: Lauren N.

description: very artistic stairway that is basically a mosiac that reminded me of the 7 days of creation. Although they are missing humans on as the "7th day" my friend said that if you stand at the bottom of the stairs, you are the 7th day of creation. Anyways, very nice artwork, good photo opportunity and the stairs lead to a great view and to another set of stairs that lead to grand view park (review here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/grand-view-park-san-francisco#hrid:BOu7GWWzXda02BXEC0FRpA) Either way its a good place to bring out of towners
author: Robert Y.

description: Fantastic picturesque stairs! Great photo-ops. Great views! Great exercise! Kudos to the people that dedicated time and money to this project!
author: Peter L.

description:
2007 went out fighting in spectacular form with the most intense blazing orange sunset reflecting against the corrugated clouds. This sparkling mosaic staircase was the perfect place to bear witness to this glorious sight bowed across the expanse of sky and ruminate on the past and kindle hopes for the new year.  Quite a wonderful spot.

Happy 2008 everyone.
author: GIR ..

description:
It's fun to walk up stairs. It's fun to walk up stairs. It's fun to walk up stairs. It's fun to walk up stairs. It's fun to walk up stairs. 

Remember that mantra as you're walking up those stairs. Here, it actually is fun. And beautiful. The steps have been renovated in recent years and now have a seascape mosaic on the sides of the steps. The design is beautiful when you stand at the bottom and stare up. But then you must walk up because the view is stunning.
author: Valerie V.

description: Wow, this is breathtaking and I am so proud to have it in my neighborhood! What a great project.
author: Chris I.

description: I love the steps. As you walk all the way up the stairs it's a breath taking view of the outer sunset. The steps are very unique, but I especially love crescent moon. =)
author: Mandy D.

description: What a fabulous set of stairs!!! A friend suggested we check this spot out since we were visiting sf and it is def a place to check out. They did a really good job on the mosaic- absolutely gorgeous. And if u continue with the next set of stairs and reach the top, there is a breathtaking view of the city. I love those type of spots the most and def recommend anyone stop by at least once.
author: Di L.

description:
LOVE these steps.  Such a great way to take a stretch of concrete and make it beautiful.   I used to see these from afar and wonder what the hell it was, and finally I went to check it out and was blown away.   Go see for yourself, you won't be disappointed.

...And while you're at the 16th avenue steps you might as well walk a little bit further and go up to Grand View Park for some spectacular views of the city.  So once you go to the top of the steps you'll be on 15th ave.   Go right a little ways, then go up another staircase (don't worry it's not very long), then you'll go right again to the steps that lead up to the peak of Grand View.  Have fun, enjoy it.  Bring something warm: clothing,coffee..
author: Kevin A.

description: So i live like two blocks away from these steps and everytime i drive by there is some gawkers gawking at these steps and i'm just like "WHO CARES?" but i guess i say that because i live so close. These are just stairs people with a nice view of (usually covered with fog) the pacific ocean. It's cold and windy at the top and you won't stay there long. it's only nice on a sunny day. The plants on the sides are alright.. just wild flowers. The only great thing about these stairs is my memories of me and my high school AP English class group shooting a trailer for Crime and Punishment using these stairs as a recurring symbol. Good times all around.
author: Liz R.

description: shhh this place is a secret! these steps are awesome! so beautiful and colorful!
author: cheryl d.

description: Very nice steps! You can see a beautiful view toward the sea from the highest step. You can park your car on a street and walk to the steps.
author: David B.

description: If you are lucky enough to visit this stairway during a clear skied sunset you won't be disappointed. Looks like it was built by local hands and is such a wonderful use of space. This stairway combined with the stairs at grand view park make for a mean workout with rewarding views. Top shelf sunset hidden gem.
author: Nate S.

description:
beautiful views and work as you ascend this staircase. it looks like a lot of hard work went into this project. and once you reach the top why not climb another bunch of stairs to check out the view at grand view park a destination in itself.  

http://www.tiledsteps.org/Default.asp
author: roger b.

description: I have some fond memories of hanging out on these steps in my senior year of high school, and a little afterward. My BF lived around here and I would often get of the N, hike up here and wait for him to get home. It's really a nice view of the city on clear nights, and a great place to sit and talk to friends...
author: Allyson S.

description: These steps are beautiful.  They are one of those hidden treasures of San Francisco. I discovered the steps when I did a bit of volunteer work with http://www.onebrick.org  The neighbors have put a good deal of work into planting and maintenance.
author: Amy M.

description: oooooo. pretty! Who knew art could be so healthy for the body, as well... OMG - new niche - physical fitness art! Who's with me?!
author: Andrew C.

description: In my mind, this is the stairway to heaven.  I live nearby, and make a point to go by it as often as possible, especially around sunset.  the colors from the west gleam off the mirrored artwork that make it look surreal.  Try looking at the steps from the ground up, then go small sections up at a time and see how the colors of the sun and sky change off the mirrored artwork, depending on the angle.  The artwork itself is often an interpretation big sweeps of nature that surrounds the region--sun, surf, stars).  The views looking outward of the Pacific, the Marin Coast, and the Golden Gate Bridge are picture perfect.  I hope this doesn't bring the tourists here--tell them there are killer bees living in the succulents if you see them here.
author: Ken H.

description: We found these amazing steps thanks to Adah Bakalinsky;s Stairway Walks in San Francisco. We just moved to SF a year ago and these steps have been a highlight of getting to know our city.
author: Susan G.

description: One of my favorite things about San Francisco has to be the hidden steps and stairways scattered across the city - and the tiled steps do not disappoint.  Standing at the bottom of the stairs, it might take your breath away to see all of the small, beautifully placed tiles forming a wave of amazing sealife extending up, up, up...but catch that breath fast because you've now got to start your walk up to the top!  Once you get to the top, you'll be rewarded with a wonderful view that extends all the way to ocean beach.  Try to go on a clear day (yeah, I know, that doesn't happen out this way often, but try) for the best view.  The tiles are amazing and I feel so lucky to have been able to spend time walking the stairs!
author: Rachel G.

description: So beautiful and unexpected!  Caught a fleeting glance as I drove past and wondered if I'd hallucinated.  Had to go back and take a second look, this one much longer.  Such a great bit of public art, enriching the neighborhood immeasurably.
author: Teal H.

description: Walking down these steps with someone special and looking up is quite amazing and priceless,,,,awwwww moment!!
author: Cali G.

description: This has to be added to the list of Modern World Wonders. It's absolutely breath taking from the bottom of the steps and once you reach the top. My first time here was on a school field trip to find the most nature preserved areas in the City. It's quite a climb but so worth the trip once you reach the top. Make sure to bring a camera!
author: True C.

description: I love it.  One of the very few "can't misses" for friends and families.  It is a quick walk from my house, and it leads to the most amazing view in the entire city.  YAY!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Its so exciting to see this bright and cheery stairs come into view. Hurray for people who love to make their neighborhood beautiful! And then climbing up them you can alternate between looking down admiring the beautiful tile mosiac (I loved the mirrored ones) and pausing to glance over your shoulder to see the Golden Gate Bridge and the fog come rolling in over the Sunset. Very cool indeed.
author: Megan G.

description: A spectacular journey to the top with a gorgeous view of the city once you arrive. A must see. I miss the Sunset!
author: Joseph M.

description: I love this find -  I call it the "secret stair case" but in fact nearly everyone must know about it.  It is so beautiful! I like to go to watch the sunset.
author: sarah w.

description: love it there.. went there twice during the week im in town hehe... very tranquil and unique spot.. a good change from the tourists laden places..
author: J W.

description: i thought these were called the moraga steps.... who knew there was a real name.  i come here once in a while to walk up. i like the moon steps the best. i think they should put some lights here for night time though. scary at night
author: just k.
